commit_message:
Add project templates for functional and upgrades

In order to make our lives easier, we'll switch to using
project-templates from now on and minimize the amount of
inconsistency across roles.

Change-Id: I2608fc5a0230436cebb0e6c579deae7bd4d7c209

commit_message:
Remove all non-voting jobs

The correct way is to mark a job non-voting in the project
section rather than having a non-voting job.  This will make
life easier in switching things on and off later.

Change-Id: I534fa8852c0af01007aa115fe29603e7c648800b

commit_message:
Replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url"

Based on the change in Keystone Install Guide [1],
this patch replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url".

For more details, please check similar changes which have been done
on other projects: Nova [2], Neutron [3], Cinder [4], Glance [5].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541857
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562812
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566491
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565464
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558932

Change-Id: Ic3d67f6ef1f7fe980154887b62e38155985573c8

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 12:31:43.000000000', 'message': "Drop usage of nova_spice_distro_packages in the role

There was a commit 3 years ago which switched to installing SPICE
from source rather than from packages.  It also included a section
which would 'remove' and 'cleanup' packages for SPICE which was
not removed.

With time, it looks like we've added it to the list of things to
install, only to uninstall it in the next task.  This removes all
of this extra cruft and further removes our dependency on EPEL.

Change-Id: I9bbe109d50040bbc02b194f9486ab581a6cc51a9
"}]
commit_message:
Drop usage of nova_spice_distro_packages in the role

There was a commit 3 years ago which switched to installing SPICE
from source rather than from packages.  It also included a section
which would 'remove' and 'cleanup' packages for SPICE which was
not removed.

With time, it looks like we've added it to the list of things to
install, only to uninstall it in the next task.  This removes all
of this extra cruft and further removes our dependency on EPEL.

Change-Id: I9bbe109d50040bbc02b194f9486ab581a6cc51a9

commit_message:
Add retries to install packages required for Neutron

Jobs sometimes fail and timeout on this task so adding retries
to make it less prone to CI failures.

Change-Id: I4ecad7ecf56962fc272989a8fafc66b0ff1e5185

commit_message:
Set the BTRFS mixed flag when creating the BTRFS volumes

This change sets the mixed flag when the BTRFS storage volume is first
created. This will ensure chucks are not divided which will further
assist in ensuing we're not running up against storage limitations
epsecially whith small volumes.

More on this can be found here:
  * https://btrfs.wiki.kernel.org/index.php/Manpage/mkfs.btrfs

Change-Id: Ib3de25df43abcf8ff31f1a991990b39f3f5cd8e5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
[DO NOT MERGE] use openstackconfig instead of ini_setting for keystone_config

keystone supports multi-valued options (e.g.,
federation/trusted_dashboard), which requires the openstackconfig
provider.

Change-Id: Ic516d9d2f5c32a3fc3f77c0db9375f951300c949

[{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-01-26 15:30:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-05-14 15:13:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-05-14 16:28:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Looks good, but I'm missing context - why can't they be implemented for libvirt? 
Perhaps commit message can have an explanation why? How/why they were added initially?"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-05-16 16:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well, to be clear, not everything here cannot be implemented at all. Things like PartNumber probably don't make sense for virt. Processor family can potentially be implemented, but I haven't found how so far.

I guess a more correct summary of this commit would be "Clean up items that are not implemented yet".'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-05-16 16:44:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 23630, 'date': '2018-05-16 16:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27909, 'date': '2018-05-17 07:27:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-05-18 15:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-05-18 15:59:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We have a static simulator for those who want to try their stuff against a static JSON, so not sure this is valuable here.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-05-21 15:52:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> We have a static simulator for those who want to try their stuff against a static JSON, so not sure this is valuable here.

/me is balancing at the edge of bikeshedding - my point here is that it may make sense to emulate everything we can emulate convincingly and ditch the stuff that we do not really emulate.

From that perspective, retaining things like 'Manufacturer' does not seem to hurt.

But I will keep enjoying life even if you decide to purge that stuff away. ;-)"}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-08 16:53:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-18 19:11:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-18 19:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-18 19:24:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1

I feel confident with two other reviewers. Approving.'}]

commit_message:
Clean up unused items from templates

The standard does not mandate most of the fields, so we don't have
to provide fake values and links to non-existing resources.

Change-Id: I45e2701db1de2fd342083e46114a2d276417a632

'}, {'created': '2018-05-11 09:36:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix power status command error reporting

commit_message:
Fix power status command error reporting

With pyghmi API, some methods return generic IPMI error
codes, while some return payload values. This patch fixes
the `get_power_state()` method to raise exception instead
of returning IPMI error code because the latter goes against
pyghmi API.

Change-Id: If30c1ee49982a7a1198a39a7afdc1edc2c516078

commit_message:
Add an option to bind simulators to a local interface

This change adds the `--interface` option to the simulator
programes to let users bind simulators to listen at
specific local interfaces.

Change-Id: Ifa559258cdc530929107f9da6a158868a1aaf5f5

commit_message:
Mark IBM GPFS driver unsupported

The IBM GPFS driver has not run 3rd Party CI
in more than 60 days.  This patch marks it
unsupported and it will be removed in Stein
if the 3rd Party CI Issues are not resolved.

Change-Id: I2958b9b310edd89f7ef1fa050b2851cb9b33842e

commit_message:
Replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url"

Based on the change in Keystone Install Guide [1],
this patch replace port 35357 with 5000 for "auth_url".

For more details, please check similar changes which have been done
on other projects: Nova [2], Neutron [3], Cinder [4], Glance [5].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541857
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/562812
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566491
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565464
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558932

Change-Id: I485342b98b8c8d832a5deed2d287e375fccc349a

[{'created': '2018-06-18 13:20:24.000000000', 'message': 'Remove manila::backend::cephfsnative

This class was deprecated in favor of
manila::backend::cephfs, providing the same
set of configuration options with the ability
to configure nfs-ganesha opts as well.

Change-Id: Ib13dfc6ffa77e96f5738c2ca3f9646a80aded659
'}]
commit_message:
Remove manila::backend::cephfsnative

This class was deprecated in favor of
manila::backend::cephfs, providing the same
set of configuration options with the ability
to configure nfs-ganesha opts as well.

Change-Id: Ib13dfc6ffa77e96f5738c2ca3f9646a80aded659

Update python-manilaclient to 1.17.3

The stable/pike branch has accumulated some important bug fixes since
its last release.

Review to bump up python-manilaclient release to 1.17.3 (merged):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575355/

Change-Id: I278ba108618d726bb4e7c8c39f2d113a8bb651d2

commit_message:
Treat unknown fields as subcontrollers

This patch changes get_one methods of the API exposed resources
to take into account the existence of the field requested in the
path. If the only single field is specified, for example
/nodes/node-0/abcd, and the respective resource does not contain
such field, we treat it as a subcontroller, and return 404 as this
subcontroller does not exist, instead of returning 400 assuming
that an invalid field was requested. The behavior changes only
for API microversions 1.32 and later.

Closes-Bug: #1640546
Change-Id: I38c5cf0019cfd263b4621443175a463cb3f18575

commit_message:
Switch role name from Member to member

keystone is creating default roles for member since [1]. This
is "member" and it's not configurable so we need to switch it
in p-o-i too to avoid conflicting names errors (keystone is not
case sensitive in object names).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572243/

Depends-On: Icd91bd27d0c0f375d2e99e9c018d3971fc49ce18
Change-Id: Id838d69e4ace9b2ea6c2a9cc6f8fd079d2115dd6

The ImageUnacceptable exception gets thrown here [1] before we could catch it where we expected to here [2]. Rather than translating our CertificateValidationFailed exception to an ImageUnacceptable exception to a BuildAbort exception, maybe we should just skip the ImageUnacceptable exception. In other words, translate from CertificateValidationFailed to BuildAbort here [3] and here [4].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L2030-L2033

[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L2094-L2110

[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L7482-L7486

[4] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L7712-L7718'}, {'account_id': 24711, 'date': '2018-04-11 01:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 50:

commit_message:
Implement certificate_utils

Implement the certificate_utils module. The module's verify_certificate
method can be applied to the creation or rebuild of an instance. It is
triggered by one of two ways:
    1) The enable_certificate_validation configuration option is set to
       True in Nova's glance configuration (alongside the
       verify_glance_signatures option also set to True)
    2) A list of trusted certificate IDs is provided

Change-Id: I0ae2dbf66241207a425bf7d0fc02a4d2e2dea409
Implements: blueprint nova-validate-certificates

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-16 12:42:00.000000000', 'message': 'Remove confusing DB deprecation messages

When share instances were introduced a number of fields
were moved in the database model to the underlying share instance
and proxied back to the share in order to maintain compatability
with APIs that assume these to belong to the share.  A deprecation
warning was added for these.  The warning spams the API log and
confuses end users because it sounds like they or their client
should make a change to get rid of them and that cannot actually
be done.  The API would have to change to expose share instances
to end users rather than just administrators and that is not
something that we plan to do.

Remove these confusing warnings.

Closes-Bug: #1776947

Change-Id: I95e99b26f416bbf25cfd1c8f7295f3ba6220efb3
(cherry picked from commit 8bdbbd86ae8efe05950ad0651c40aa17c8ec71c7)

commit_message:
Remove confusing DB deprecation messages

When share instances were introduced a number of fields
were moved in the database model to the underlying share instance
and proxied back to the share in order to maintain compatability
with APIs that assume these to belong to the share.  A deprecation
warning was added for these.  The warning spams the API log and
confuses end users because it sounds like they or their client
should make a change to get rid of them and that cannot actually
be done.  The API would have to change to expose share instances
to end users rather than just administrators and that is not
something that we plan to do.

Remove these confusing warnings.

Closes-Bug: #1776947

Change-Id: I95e99b26f416bbf25cfd1c8f7295f3ba6220efb3
(cherry picked from commit 8bdbbd86ae8efe05950ad0651c40aa17c8ec71c7)

subject: Remove deploy playbook from `update run`
messages: [{'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-06-13 15:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-06-18 13:39:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nLGTM'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-13 15:36:19.000000000', 'message': "Remove deploy playbook from `update run`

We need the deploy steps as part of update playbook, to execute them
with `serial: 1` (we need to start services on node A before
proceeding to update node B). This is already happening correctly
within the update playbook.

After the update playbook we have been additionaly running deploy
playbook on all nodes in parallel. That seems like a superfluous
operation, in some environments considerably prolonging the time for
minor update. The full deployment will be once again executed on all
nodes in parallel during `update converge`, we don't need to do it in
`update run` too.

Change-Id: I513f655707c8a31f3621b96a756be9c468e3bd8b
Closes-Bug: #1776206
(cherry picked from commit 560e467016db6121b421e059e4751e912a566400)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove deploy playbook from `update run`

We need the deploy steps as part of update playbook, to execute them
with `serial: 1` (we need to start services on node A before
proceeding to update node B). This is already happening correctly
within the update playbook.

After the update playbook we have been additionaly running deploy
playbook on all nodes in parallel. That seems like a superfluous
operation, in some environments considerably prolonging the time for
minor update. The full deployment will be once again executed on all
nodes in parallel during `update converge`, we don't need to do it in
`update run` too.

Change-Id: I513f655707c8a31f3621b96a756be9c468e3bd8b
Closes-Bug: #1776206
(cherry picked from commit 560e467016db6121b421e059e4751e912a566400)

subject: Fix access control for single host addresses
messages: [{'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2018-06-15 03:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-06-15 10:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6491, 'date': '2018-06-18 16:52:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 03:22:29.000000000', 'message': 'Fix access control for single host addresses

In CIDR notation, the max prefix-length is typically
used to denote individual host addresses, for example:
2620:52:0:13b8::fe:e7 and 2620:52:0:13b8::fe:e7/128
are semantically the same.

Fix the access-allow API to raise 400 Bad Request if
an address by either notation already exists in the
manila database for a given share.

Change-Id: I6e790fd0edd82064a3c5cda8a919c9eeb2da85d0
Closes-Bug: 1767430
(cherry picked from commit 50f957eefdd97eca470ae66adad3e993aa8aaaa8)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix access control for single host addresses

In CIDR notation, the max prefix-length is typically
used to denote individual host addresses, for example:
2620:52:0:13b8::fe:e7 and 2620:52:0:13b8::fe:e7/128
are semantically the same.

Fix the access-allow API to raise 400 Bad Request if
an address by either notation already exists in the
manila database for a given share.

Change-Id: I6e790fd0edd82064a3c5cda8a919c9eeb2da85d0
Closes-Bug: 1767430
(cherry picked from commit 50f957eefdd97eca470ae66adad3e993aa8aaaa8)

subject: Explicit Data Types
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8215, 'name': 'Tim Hinrichs', 'email': 'timothy.l.hinrichs@gmail.com', 'username': 'thinrich'}, {'_account_id': 8878, 'name': 'Masahito Muroi', 'email': 'masahito.muroi@linecorp.com', 'username': 'masa'}, {'_account_id': 11278, 'name': 'Anusha Ramineni', 'email': 'anusha.ramineni@india.nec.com', 'username': 'anusha08'}, {'_account_id': 18591, 'name': 'Eric Kao', 'email': 'ekcs.openstack@gmail.com', 'username': 'ekcs'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23518, 'name': 'Pierre Cr√©gut', 'email': 'pierre.cregut@orange.com', 'username': 'pcregut'}, {'_account_id': 25553, 'name': 'Akhil jain', 'email': 'akhiljain32@gmail.com', 'username': 'akhil'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-24 01:04:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-04-24 09:10:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

My main problem is that I don't understand what is a type in this setting beyond primitive types."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-25 00:13:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Hi Pierre, thank you for the comments!

Yes I definitely left out important pieces of information on what exactly constitutes a type. I'll clarify in the document after discussion. Looking forward to hearing what you think!

A preliminary thought is that a non-primitive type is a Python class that includes the following pieces:
1. an __init__ method that takes arbitrary JSON structure as input and either creates a value of the type or rejects by raising an exception. This method serves as a contract on the exact boundaries of the type.
2. extends another type (primitive or not) and be treatable as a value of the parent type.

Put in context of the octant type system ( https://github.com/Orange-OpenSource/octant/blob/master/octant/datalog_primitives.py ), 1 and 2 essentially takes the 
place of marshall and unmarshall methods, whereas the z3 and os methods are left up to each policy engine.

On 2, I'm not clear on whether to borrow the Python inheritance mechanism for this purpose. One benefit of using the Python inheritance mechanism is that we can re-use something standard: the hierarchy can be accessed via isinstance, and treatment as a parent type is automatic. The drawback is that inheriting from primitive python types can get needlessly complicated. My sense is the drawbacks outweigh the benefits."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-26 02:19:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-26 02:21:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Pierre,

I've uploaded a new version to make much more concrete what types are and how they are defined. Some of your other comments will be addressed in a future version."}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-04-26 07:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I think I mostly agree with the specification. I would like to add two points:

* Explicitly talking of type merging and why we need a join-semi-lattice structure.
* The main alternative for me would be standard python base types + tags.

Union of types
--------------
If you have relations FA(X:A) and FB(X:B) where A and B are the types of the respective arguments,
you can define P such that P(X) :- FA(X) and P(X) :- FB(X). In that case the type of B is P(X: A U B).
Even with simple base types, we may have to convert values. 

Today our T (top) type is str. You can always use it as join. But we may ask if 4 is "4" when we merge str and int.  Some engines may prefer to use a more specific join (for example for intervals you can use the interval between min and max bounds).

Types as pure intentional tags
------------------------------
Actual representation of types will be different for each engine. Even if we provide a parsing/unparsing pair there will be more an additional coding/uncoding function in the engine. For example octant only handle bitvectors internally. In that case it may be simpler to let the engine provide its own function from source representation to internal representation and the agnostic engine will probably use no translation at all. 
There are still a few internal initial types which are the python base types (str, int, boolean, float).
So a type could be just a tag indicating a potential meaning and a typed value would be a raw primitive python value and a tag type. The problem would then be keeping those tag standardized enough so that engine can do something useful with them.

I admit I am not sure of the right choice here. What is alluring in this approach is that we do not commit to anything. There is no fixed set of CongressDataType subclasses. But if for example you want to use interval types, the engine must figure out what an interval is. Note that even in your proposal, source_to_internal and converse function will not provide any clue as they would be the identity type.'}, {'account_id': 8215, 'date': '2018-04-26 17:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-26 20:42:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Thanks Tim for the comment! I think we're on the same page there, but it wasn't made clear in the document."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-04-27 00:09:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thank you Pierre! Very helpful discussion.

I think the approach I'm proposing here is a slight extension of _types as pure intentional tags_ approach. The subclasses of CongressDataType are essentially intentional tags. The exact boundary of the intended type is declared in the `source_to_internal` method. That is, `val` is in the source space of Type if and only if `Type.source_to_internal(val)` succeeds. Correspondingly, `repr` is in the internal representation space of `Type` if and only if there exists a `val` such that `Type.source_to_internal(val)` produces `repr`. So the `source_to_internal` method is the contract/documentation (programmers of) policy engines can count on in processing a value.

The flow of how the types are actually used was not clear in the current revision of the spec. I'll be adding clarifying in next revision, but for now you can refer to my response here [1].

There is no fixed set of CongressDataType subclasses. Any data source driver (even custom ones not included in Congress repo) can arbitrarily declare and use new subclasses.

As you said,
>> The problem would then be keeping those tag standardized enough so that engine can do something useful with them.

While some of the types will be completely arbitrary tags that policy engines can only use with special code to handle that type, some of the types can be meaningfully organized in ways that help policy engines handle the data. For example, all the finite domain types can mix in a special abstract class [2] that the policy engine can rely on to handle arbitrary types that implement the abstract class. A similar abstract class can be used for interval types and others.

------

I agree that the policy engine chooses its own representations. The `source_to_internal` and method is first and foremost a way to document to the policy engine programmer what to expect as input, and only secondarily as aids to the policy engine programmer in processing the input data. The term 'internal representation' used in the Congress data type may be misleading. It's really a storage and transmission representation used by the data source driver and the congress data bus. Perhaps 'transmission representation' or 'raw value' is more understandable?

------

I agree with saying more about the union of types. We can make sure to require a join-semi-lattice structure, perhaps by making CongressStr the top type.

I think there is an interesting point you're making here. Could you elaborate on the following?

>> But we may ask if 4 is "4" when we merge str and int. 


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/563799/2/specs/rocky/explicit-data-types.rst@149

[2] I forgot to paste this into the last revision. It was supposed to go here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/563799/2/specs/rocky/explicit-data-types.rst@174

@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta)
class CongressTypeBoundedDomain(object):
    '''Abstract base class for a Congress type of bounded domain.'''

    @classmethod
    @abc.abstractmethod
    def domain_size(cls):
        '''Return the size of the domain.

        The internal representation must be an integer x where
        0 <= x < domain_size()'''
        raise NotImplementedError'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-01 01:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-01 01:37:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Substantially re-worked to be much clearer and more complete. The proposed change section is now intended to be complete.

Thanks again for all the super helpful early discussions!'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-01 23:50:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-01 23:54:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The alternatives section updated. Pierre, I think the pure intentional tag alternative you discussed is a combination of 4 and 5.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/563799/4/specs/rocky/explicit-data-types.rst@611'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-05-14 08:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Fine for me. I am not totally convinced that distinguishing the exchange format and the source format (mostly string) is worth the effort, but it is mostly irrelevant (most of the code will stay the same if we decide for example to keep the representation of IP address as a string).

The fact that the Datalog type hierarchy (with single inheritance) is coded by Python type hierarchy (with multiple inheritance) should be more explicit (CongressDatatype _get_parent implementation is really a key method to understand it).'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-18 01:57:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-18 20:10:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thank you Pierre!

Let me just make sure I understand your thinking. I think you're saying it's sufficient to adopt a simpler alternative of either 4 or 5 or both. Is that right?

5: use the same representation for exchange and for presentation to user
4: use the same representation between parent and child, with the exception of the ultimate conversion to string from a non-string type

I also prefer a simpler approach unless there is a clear need to go beyond. I think we should adopt both of those simplifications unless someone sees a strong reason not to."}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-05-22 10:27:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Yes I think we should use a representation closer to 4. How we display values (5) is not really relevant but usually the user representation will be the canonic representation of the exchange representation.

The set of root types should be Python (or json) primitive types (string, int, floats, booleans) which is more or less what we have today in the agnostic engine. 

I am not sure we should force everything to be a string. If we have a number from a datasource there is no reason to convert it back to a string unless we must merge strings and number columns. But we should not have for example intervals or discrete integer values with a smarter representation than the value itself. Or enumerations (strings) represented by something else but the initial string value.

Smart representations are the realm of the engines and they will probably have different ones.

Other types have values that are implicitly pairs of a type tag and a value of a root type. It is important to have those tags so that engines can use the right internal representation but they do not modify the exchange representation. If we have only one engine, there won't be much conversion."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-05-28 20:16:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks Pierre! I'll update the spec accordingly."}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-06-05 21:50:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-06-05 23:46:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Pierre, spec updated according to your comments.'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-06-06 12:11:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

Looks great to me ! 
The only remark is that the last alternative is now rather the spec proposal and a true alternative would be types with heavy conversion between each level in the hierarchy.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-06-06 20:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-06-06 20:15:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Ah thanks for catching that oversight. Updated!'}, {'account_id': 23518, 'date': '2018-06-11 07:03:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8878, 'date': '2018-06-15 06:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 25553, 'date': '2018-06-18 09:04:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-06-18 17:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Workflow+1

Thanks all!'}]

commit_message:
Explicit Data Types

In preparation to support more policy engines in addition to the standard
Congress policy engine (e.g., ones based on SQL, influxDB, or Z3), we need
explicit typing of table columns in the data sources and the
data service engine. This spec proposes to support explicit typing, including
custom types, in an extensible, evolutionary, and backwards-compatible manner.

Change-Id: I389ff5fc8c7cdf9ca3b145c5eb8826f6e6cd28fa

commit_message:
Move L3 agent checks inside overcloud upgrade script.

Currently L3 agent checks are called from ansible tasks,
 though those scripts already exist at uc.
Current change calls those scripts from within `upgrade` script,
 which makes it easier for local reproducing.

Change-Id: Ib3a781f570155a2139b6e0cf3debfc97363c6a08
(cherry picked from commit 651da4a0165e2b8351583d45911ca2f389aee03d)

[{'created': '2018-06-13 04:21:53.000000000', 'message': "Add log artifacts for upgrade steps

Context: https://trello.com/c/vJwmd6SD/771-indexing-upgrade-logs-in-logstash
         https://trello.com/c/TU3JEtmg/560-ensure-upgrade-logging

- Per feedback have added timestamper_cmd so these
  logs can be indexed by logstash.

- for clarity have added a distinct variable for update template

- for clarity have added ffu_ prefix to FFU variant of UC upgrade template

- Per feedback removed the logging from bash jinja template
  as it's inconsistent with logging norms in TQ/TQE

I suggest that we also rename undercloud_upgrade.sh.j2 to reflect
that it's used in both upgrade and update workflows, or we clearly
disambiguate and fully denormalize by duplicating the template.  In order
to limit scope/risk IMHO this should be done in a discreet commit.

Change-Id: I184c5ebd28ae11a93a854df5dc2cafd02a5e1b6c
(cherry picked from commit baff4a25229b1904e960e426208eca76c96c3ab4)

commit_message:
Add log artifacts for upgrade steps

Context: https://trello.com/c/vJwmd6SD/771-indexing-upgrade-logs-in-logstash
         https://trello.com/c/TU3JEtmg/560-ensure-upgrade-logging

- Per feedback have added timestamper_cmd so these
  logs can be indexed by logstash.

- Per feedback removed the logging from bash jinja template
  as it's inconsistent with logging norms in TQ/TQE

Change-Id: I184c5ebd28ae11a93a854df5dc2cafd02a5e1b6c
(cherry picked from commit baff4a25229b1904e960e426208eca76c96c3ab4)

the horizon::keystone_url is ultimately used to set the
OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL setting in Horizon's local_settings, and this

commit_message:
use keystone public endpoint in horizon

the horizon::keystone_url is ultimately used to set the
OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL setting in Horizon's local_settings, and this
is used in browser redirects when utilizing web SSO. In many cases,
the keystone internal endpoint would be inaccessible to browser
clients, so we should use the public endpoint here.

Change-Id: I5b3c0935b1a5c38704e748770b7bac52d674a637

commit_message:
Remove duplicate test_unmanage_volume test

This patchset removes the duplicate test_umanage_volume test
from test_volume_actions_rbac [0] because it is more appropriate
to keep it in test_volumes_manage_rbac [1]. Besides the latter
implementation is more robust.

commit_message:
Make auth_encryption_key a secret

auth_encryption_key is used to encrypt autentication info in the
database, it must be a secret.

Change-Id: Ib15db2632d087b91ca4923a64fa9923daa6b2c85
(cherry picked from commit 24cbbd517a997a192619e89de28cfad60ea4f264)

subject: Retrieve cloud credentials directly from keystone
messages:
[{'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-14 10:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-14 12:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-06-15 18:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

A couple of typos in the commit message.

This is a good light touch approach, however, there is no handling of required vs optional interfaces to keystone. How will the end user know it is missing a relation to keystone in a V2 cell?

It would also be good to have a functional test for this. Maybe bionic-queens+ uses keystone directly?'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-18 08:31:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-18 08:43:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the review David, I have slightly reworded the commit message and fixed a typo. You are absolutely right than in a cells deployment the required/optional interface assessment code will need updating but this is only the first part. There will be a subsequent change to this charm which adds a new 'cell-name' configuration option. Once that is in place the interface assessment code can be updated correctly. I would rather wait for that than add a stop-gap piece of assessment code which would ultimately be thrown away.
Similarly, I wonder if it would be better to include a cells functional test in the nova-compute charm once the cells pieces are in place, this would exercise the new nova-compute cloud-credentials relation. I think that would be a closes fit to our aim of black-box testing rather than having a new functional test just to test this new relation."}, {'account_id': 12549, 'date': '2018-06-18 12:20:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Actually I was wrong, the cell-name config option is in nova-cc not in nova-compute.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2018-06-18 16:43:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

The long term plan will add the functional testing and work load status. Merging this interim step.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 10:16:16.000000000', 'message': 'Retrieve cloud credentials directly from keystone

In a cells deployment the credentials for the nova-compute
application will no longer be available via the
nova-cloud-controller in the local cell. This change adds the
cloud-credentials relation to the charm so that is can
retrieve credeentials directly from keystone.

Change-Id: I9d1a7353d730f7cb8e93cc9eea5b788f7c956c3d
'}, {'created': '2018-06-18 08:31:43.000000000', 'message': 'Retrieve cloud credentials directly from keystone

In a cells deployment the credentials for the nova-compute
application will no longer be available via the
nova-cloud-controller in the local cell. This change adds the
scaffolding for a cell to utilise a new cloud-credentials relation
to allow it to retrieve credentials directly from keystone.

Change-Id: I9d1a7353d730f7cb8e93cc9eea5b788f7c956c3d
'}]
commit_message:
Retrieve cloud credentials directly from keystone

In a cells deployment the credentials for the nova-compute
application will no longer be available via the
nova-cloud-controller in the local cell. This change adds the
scaffolding for a cell to utilise a new cloud-credentials relation
to allow it to retrieve credentials directly from keystone.

Change-Id: I9d1a7353d730f7cb8e93cc9eea5b788f7c956c3d

commit_message:
Make roles for ec2api-tester configurable

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572243/ is changing default role
name to "member" instead of "Member" so let's make it configurable
so that we can change from deployment tools when needed.

I'm keeping default as Member for backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: Icd91bd27d0c0f375d2e99e9c018d3971fc49ce18

'}, {'created': '2018-06-16 00:24:00.000000000', 'message': 'Gate fix: Rename Member (legacy) to member role

Due to a recent change, Member role is not being
found automatically following the devstack installation
script. This is causing all the member-based
gates to fail. Because "Member" is legacy [0],
this patchset uses "member" instead of "Member"
during the devstack Patrole plugin.

This patchset also specifies which role was not found in
the system while trying to resolve roles CONF.identity.admin_role
and CONF.patrole.rbac_test_role in order to make debugging
easier.

commit_message:
Gate fix: Rename Member (legacy) to member role

Due to a recent change [0], Member role is no longer
being found, as it has been renamed to member. This is
causing all the member-based gates to fail. Because "Member"
is legacy [1], this patchset uses "member" instead of "Member"
during the devstack Patrole plugin for master. For n-1
and n-2 releases "Member" is still used.

This patchset also specifies which role was not found in
the system while trying to resolve roles CONF.identity.admin_role
and CONF.patrole.rbac_test_role in order to make debugging
easier.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572243/
[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/devstack/tree/lib/keystone#n355

Change-Id: I7b59bab164041b26ed8a1a798546e493f22f6edd

commit_message:
Call base from_dict in RequestContext

This changes the from_dict override to call the base class
implementation with the Masakari-specific keys passed as kwargs.
It should prevent issues where a new key is added to the base to_dict
function that is not an accepted parameter on the constructor.

Co-Authored-By: Shilpa Devharakar <Shilpa.Devharakar@nttdata.com>
Change-Id: I9d481400c7578c986238138e8baeca05e416b2d0
Closes-Bug: 1721432

commit_message:
Make cron-triggers not play catchup

Currently if the API is stopped for a length and restarted the crontrigger
jobs will have their next execution in the past and will do a catchup
running a lot of times. That happens because the next execution is
calculated based on the first time it was executed. This change makes it be
the next execution time be the max of the calculated time and utcnow so
that if the server is lagging we keep uptodate with the calculated next
execution times.

Change-Id: I05b35261b1adbe17a1b0316eee95da12634c3978
Closes-bug: 1719882

commit_message:
bump constraints for neutron-lib to 1.14.0

In some cases, the 'neutron-db-manage' utility fails with an error
'ImportError: cannot import name dhcpagentscheduler' because of
outdated neutrons-lib version.

The 'dhcpagentscheduler' rehomed from the 'neutron' repo to the
'neutron-lib' in the I50e7616afa18c27571df3e77248e73203d1bf7de and
available only since 1.14.0.

We need to raise the version of the neutron-lib and otherdependencies
to fix the neutron issue with obsolete version while build from the
sources.

Change-Id: I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Use extension fip-port-details from neutron-lib

The fip-port-details extension's API definition was added into
neutron-lib with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534882/
This patch consumes it by using the API definition.

It also bumps the requires to use neutron-lib 1.14.0

NeutronLibImpact

We need to backport this to fix neutron-tempest-plugin-api tests
after bumping requirements for the neutron-lib in
I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for stable/queens.

Depends-On: I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22
Change-Id: I9a93c0aef247f6145f3a55a44d08844d74b44eff
(cherry picked from commit 88688fb1082d01ae6f742b03c711faa4735a4109)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Bump neutron-lib version

In some cases, the 'neutron-db-manage' utility fails with an error
'ImportError: cannot import name dhcpagentscheduler' because of
outdated neutrons-lib version.

The 'dhcpagentscheduler' rehomed from the 'neutron' repo to the
'neutron-lib' in the I50e7616afa18c27571df3e77248e73203d1bf7de and
available only since 1.14.0.

Depends-On: I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22
Change-Id: Ice47e449a19d79002093c53c5d256c64864e8643
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

commit_message:
tests/tools: add prefix "_" to CALLBACK_PRIORITY_SUPPORTED

As it's private variable in the module, add "_" prefix
to CALLBACK_PRIORITY_SUPPORTED to _CALLBACK_PRIORITY_SUPPORTED.
This patch is follow up patch for
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/560128/

This is the 2nd backport to fix issue after bumping requirements for
the neutron-lib in I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for
stable/queens.

Change-Id: I80aa34a000d1c1bd87cfff77af8fca56befe2542
(cherry picked from commit 1c36c268deca9450938b37b4fceee63aac270edf)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

commit_message:
General overhaul of testing setup

- Moved to py3 by default
- Moved to testr

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-17 16:47:53.000000000', 'message': 'unit test: unbreak test cases for callbacks.subscribe

patch set of [1] added callback priority so that a new argument, priority,
was added to subscribe method. Thus its signature was changed.
It caused to break some unit tests.[2] Those test cases check arguments passed
to subscribe method.

The fix to those test cases needs to be compatible with older version of
neutron-lib.
So add a helper method, get_subscribe_args, to produce argument to subscribe
by checking if neutron-lib supports callback priority or not. and apply it
to broken test cases.

We need to backport this to fix issue after bumping neutron-lib in
Ice47e449a19d79002093c53c5d256c64864e8643 for stable/queens.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541766/

commit_message:
unit test: unbreak test cases for callbacks.subscribe

patch set of [1] added callback priority so that a new argument, priority,
was added to subscribe method. Thus its signature was changed.
It caused to break some unit tests.[2] Those test cases check arguments passed
to subscribe method.

The fix to those test cases needs to be compatible with older version of
neutron-lib.
So add a helper method, get_subscribe_args, to produce argument to subscribe
by checking if neutron-lib supports callback priority or not. and apply it
to broken test cases.

We need to backport this to fix issue after bumping requirements for
the neutron-lib in I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for stable/queens.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/541766/
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/periodic/git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron/master/openstack-tox-py35-with-neutron-lib-master/66d328a/testr_results.html.gz
  test_capabilities.CapabilitiesTest.test_register
  test_ovs_capabilities.CapabilitiesTest.test_register
  test_backend.ServerSideRpcBackendTest.test___init__

Change-Id: I94066ff8a8dae5c5637478aa52883b3b451f2857
(cherry picked from commit 5a1934da8e2a58943cdad337b53aab8a5fcbc7ea)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

From log http://paste.openstack.org/show/723696/ which You pasted it looks that You are not using stable/queens Neutron code. In You stack trace it fails to import from neutron_lib.exceptions import dhcpagentscheduler as das_exc but when I check this file in Neutron repo in stable/queens queens, this exception are imported an used from neutron module still (not from neutron-lib): https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/stable/queens/neutron/db/agentschedulers_db.py#L34

It is changed only in master branch: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/db/agentschedulers_db.py#L24
Commit which introduced this change is only in 13.0.0.0b2 currently: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/1128619f1c2598b3b7b023a5d4a9f32d8ef5a529"}, {'account_id': 14200, 'date': '2018-06-18 15:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add port_details to Floating IP

If the floating IP is associated with a port, this attribute
will contain detailed information of the associated port. This allows
users to retrieve the floating IPs with information of its associated
port (if any) in one API call.

Other related patches:
* neutron-lib: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/534882/
* osc: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/533809/
* sdk: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/533811/
* tempest-plugin: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/561710/

APIImpact the API reference needs to be updated

We need to backport this to fix neutron-tempest-plugin-api tests
after bumping requirements for the neutron-lib in
I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for stable/queens.

Change-Id: I31e940d2986278d2fbee6fdfea4ff15f7c07ebaa
Partial-Bug: #1723026
(cherry picked from commit c760d4f26f4b4753c80269437d2cd0b8f63dbc7c)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

subject: Add standard attributes to segment resource
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-17 22:13:07.000000000', 'message': "Add standard attributes to segment resource

Standard attributes (i.e. revision_number, created_at, updated_at)
are missing in the segment resource. This is because the controller
doesn't process extensions on rendering the response. This patch
fixes it. In particular, this patch does the following:
* Process extensions when making the segment dict. This allows
  other extensions to add attributes to segment response.
* Make segment extension implement update_attributes_map.

Tempest test: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558609/

APIImpact update api reference of segments

We need to backport this to fix neutron-tempest-plugin-api tests
after bumping requirements for the neutron-lib in
I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for stable/queens.

(cherry picked from commit 4d84c10ba4430752bf8c1227c770fb3c4f0a1618)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I20aaf164ffa678eafbc8e5808e12d501e599b837
"}]
commit_message:
Add standard attributes to segment resource

Standard attributes (i.e. revision_number, created_at, updated_at)
are missing in the segment resource. This is because the controller
doesn't process extensions on rendering the response. This patch
fixes it. In particular, this patch does the following:
* Process extensions when making the segment dict. This allows
  other extensions to add attributes to segment response.
* Make segment extension implement update_attributes_map.

Tempest test: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558609/

APIImpact update api reference of segments

We need to backport this to fix neutron-tempest-plugin-api tests
after bumping requirements for the neutron-lib in
I556550d6d6487a7d8b8b369caddba73c01605d22 for stable/queens.

(cherry picked from commit 4d84c10ba4430752bf8c1227c770fb3c4f0a1618)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I20aaf164ffa678eafbc8e5808e12d501e599b837

[{'created': '2018-06-16 20:51:54.000000000', 'message': "Use Tempest master when testing roles in master

If we're testing a stable branch, it is best to use the stable
released Tempest version.  However, when working in master, it
is possible that an OpenStack service change which has a
corresponding Tempest change would lead to things failing because
we're deploying master of the service but a tagged version of
Tempest which means the tests will fail.

In order to ensure stability of stable branches, we'll keep using
the tagged release but we'll use master Tempest for testing the
roles.

Change-Id: I347afd358850149b359ae64871a858701755d896

commit_message:
Use Tempest master when testing roles in master

If we're testing a stable branch, it is best to use the stable
released Tempest version.  However, when working in master, it
is possible that an OpenStack service change which has a
corresponding Tempest change would lead to things failing because
we're deploying master of the service but a tagged version of
Tempest which means the tests will fail.

In order to ensure stability of stable branches, we'll keep using
the tagged release but we'll use master Tempest for testing the
roles.

Change-Id: I347afd358850149b359ae64871a858701755d896

commit_message:
Switch to using stestr

stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects
should migrate.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/pti/python.html

Change-Id: I3a4a8e6a7c856446686252d80046532e08d3936b

commit_message:
Queens gate fixes

This change backport the two following change for queens branch

Update kafka and dsvm jobs

Depends-On: I3232378790cff0a956db204e99e34337bbe019ff
(cherry picked from commit 865ab522cbc0edb0670b3e98d0878a4afa9f439f)

Fix oslo messaging gating

This change fixes the oslo.messaging gate for rabbit/amqp1/kafka.

Change-Id: I7d3e8332bb40678f0bc2456de76407ac06ae7f51

commit_message:
[WIP] Create network for multicast test with user parameters.

This allows to configure test scenarios for mutlicast
test by specifying network creation parameters from
tempest.conf

Depends-On: I88491dbb65031fe3743d1c3d27c38a57b5511794
Change-Id: I18cbadeecce688e7f9b7af25fcbd69cbd59ad457

messages: [{'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:45:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-18 00:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2018-06-18 07:17:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-18 14:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 15:45:53.000000000', 'message': 'Release Cinder /stable/pike 11.1.1

There have been a good number of bug fixes that have come in
since we released /stable/pike 11.1.0.  Doing a Pike
release now to roll up all the bug fixes.

Change-Id: I4ed9f24456149da5b537fda73f59b5a1fd59bee4
'}]
commit_message:
Release Cinder /stable/pike 11.1.1

There have been a good number of bug fixes that have come in
since we released /stable/pike 11.1.0.  Doing a Pike
release now to roll up all the bug fixes.

Change-Id: I4ed9f24456149da5b537fda73f59b5a1fd59bee4

commit_message:
Add microversion override for get and list

A continuation of previous patches adding support for node
get and list calls to be able to overriden with an
os_ironic_api_version keyword argument.

Also adds a release note covering the prior patches in this
series.

Change-Id: I870540a23555e6ae37659452f727872d9d7882a3
Related-Bug: #1739440
Story: #2001870
Task: #14325

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 16:51:06.000000000', 'message': 'Don't remove last char from profiling cookie path

Code was stripping last char from path when expiring the cookie that
controls profiling. For example, cookie created at /admin/info/
was being expired as /admin/info without final "/". This can fail
to find the cookie (browser dependent?) and leave profiling active
for all subsequent refreshes of the view.

Change-Id: I71d36ab3ff121cc43b8d0b43a056ba26aa030058
'}]
commit_message:
Don't remove last char from profiling cookie path

Code was stripping last char from path when expiring the cookie that
controls profiling. For example, cookie created at /admin/info/
was being expired as /admin/info without final "/". This can fail
to find the cookie (browser dependent?) and leave profiling active
for all subsequent refreshes of the view.

Change-Id: I71d36ab3ff121cc43b8d0b43a056ba26aa030058

By setting the value of rule_name explicitly, we prevent backward
incompatibility issues because the default which ceph-ansible uses
might fit a particular version of Ceph, not all.

Change-Id: I275c1ca53ea79eea607cbbb58aa21cae6d6be80b
Closes-Bug: 1776252
(cherry picked from commit dcf558628f62f12829044dbeee56047f485585f0)
'}]
commit_message:
Set Ceph pools rule_name to replicated_rule

By setting the value of rule_name explicitly, we prevent backward
incompatibility issues because the default which ceph-ansible uses
might fit a particular version of Ceph, not all.

Change-Id: I275c1ca53ea79eea607cbbb58aa21cae6d6be80b
Closes-Bug: 1776252
(cherry picked from commit dcf558628f62f12829044dbeee56047f485585f0)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 07:55:11.000000000', 'message': 'Log memcached to stdout/err only

Memcached logging configuration is not friendly.
We cannot use configuration options as they seemed to be
ignored because of a bug. We cannot use redirection >>
as this breaks logrotate signalling SIGHUP to processes
and expecting them to handle the open file descriptors
associated with truncated/removed logfiles - this does
not work with redirected output into a file.

The only option is not log memcached into a file. There is
not much of actual value in the log. Keep it logging to
stdout/stderr in its container, which will get captured in
the docker logs (and journald via the logging backend).

Co-authored-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Co-authored-by: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
Closes-bug: #1776889

Change-Id: I3b5aec6b7f7c5fa4f84e3c3eb243c155a6189e2c
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Log memcached to stdout/err only

Memcached logging configuration is not friendly.
We cannot use configuration options as they seemed to be
ignored because of a bug. We cannot use redirection >>
as this breaks logrotate signalling SIGHUP to processes
and expecting them to handle the open file descriptors
associated with truncated/removed logfiles - this does
not work with redirected output into a file.

The only option is not log memcached into a file. There is
not much of actual value in the log. Keep it logging to
stdout/stderr in its container, which will get captured in
the docker logs (and journald via the logging backend).

Co-authored-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovat@redhat.com>
Co-authored-by: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
Closes-bug: #1776889

Change-Id: I3b5aec6b7f7c5fa4f84e3c3eb243c155a6189e2c
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Just use chmod instead of file for log permissions

The file module with recurse goes to the bad place when the content has
a symlink to '.'. Rather than fighting it - just use chmod -R, which
does what we want.

Change-Id: Ied4cc2a7e252db555ffdc3f1fd47edaf93b666da

commit_message:
Add image search default use driver 'docker'

zun image search use 'docker' or 'glance' driver,
add default driver, if user not use image_driver,
the image search use default drvier 'docker'.

Change-Id: Idb5f9a8d6725258d498f9cfdb3fb1718c8abd018
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

The revisions of the requirements items that were 23 days ago caused this problem [1]. But I suggest keeping the same change-id in the cherry-pick way.'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2018-05-14 13:04:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@jian.song: Sorry, I left out the link for the patch (that introduced the problem) from the commit message. Should I add that?

About the same change-id: do you mean that the patch should be added by cherry-pick of the .stestr.conf from master? Because the problem there is that it consists of two ([1] and [2]) quite complex patches, so it complicates the cherry-pick. Isn't it enough just to mention here, that .stestr.conf is taken from master?

Thanks!

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/507087/

I think this needs ZHAO CHAO review."}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2018-05-15 07:03:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

more test detail:http://logs.openstack.org/61/568461/1/check/openstack-tox-py27/27ae9ab/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-05-15_06_47_37_557065'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-05-15 07:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > @jian.song: Sorry, I left out the link for the patch (that
 > > introduced the problem) from the commit message. Should I add
 > that?
 > >
 > > About the same change-id: do you mean that the patch should be
 > > added by cherry-pick of the .stestr.conf from master? Because the
 > > problem there is that it consists of two ([1] and [2]) quite
 > > complex patches, so it complicates the cherry-pick. Isn't it
 > enough
 > > just to mention here, that .stestr.conf is taken from master?
 > >
 > > Thanks!
 > >
 > > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/507087/
 > > [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547724/
 > 
 > I think this needs ZHAO CHAO review.

@eeldill @jian.song Sorry for late response. I did some quick look through about this problem, jian.song is right, the root cause is the version bumping of os-testr in openstack/requirements (stable/pike branch).

For the patch itself, we need to mention the change in openstack/requirements.

I think a completely new changeset ID is fine with this kind of fix. However the stable branches guidelines prefers cherry-picking. For the cherry-pick approach, there's an example from Matt Riedemann:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514710

So we may be better to go with cherry-picking (partially should be fine).

Thanks for working on this, eeldill, jian.song."}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2018-05-15 13:27:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Zhao Chao @jian.song Thanks for the reviews! I've added the link for the patch that caused the problem (os-testr version upgrade) and also used partial cherry-picking and updated the commit message accordingly.

(I needed to use the new change-id, because the original patch has already a backport on stable/pike so it cannot be used)

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 22694, 'date': '2018-05-17 09:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

thx Elod.lgtm'}, {'account_id': 13157, 'date': '2018-05-18 06:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Thanks, @eeldill, LGTM.

The version of os-testr in stable/queens is not bumped yet, otherwise we should fix stable/queens first.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-18 13:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(3 comments)

lgtm, cherry picked changes are explicitly called out in the commit message.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-18 13:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-09 17:24:42.000000000', 'message': 'Add .stestr.conf to fix tox-py27 stable job

os-testr 1.0.0 was introduced on stable/pike, which causes tox-py27 job
failure, because without .stestr.conf os-testr discovers all the tests,
not just the unit tests and runs them during py27 job. This fails due
to missing tempest.lib, which is necessary only for tempest tests.

Change-Id: I77b9f126ae5d500ff7fc7252b9acfed1c21f7db4
'}, {'created': '2018-05-15 13:19:33.000000000', 'message': "Add .stestr.conf to fix tox-py27 stable job

NOTE(elod.illes): This is a squash of two commit, but only .stestr.conf
and .gitignore is used from them.

os-testr 1.0.0 was introduced [1] on stable/pike, which causes tox-py27
job failure. The root cause of the problem is a bug, which has a fix[2]
but not part of os-testr 1.0.0 release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/563394/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/503877/

The first commit's message is:

The os-testr 1.0.0 release had a couple of required config changes due
to it's internal usage of stestr.

This change to stestr changed the way tests were discovered by
os-testr and as a result the unit test run was picking up tempest
tests.

NOTE(elod.illes): This is only taking one specific fix from the large
change on master since we don't need the other changes for stable/pike
to fix the gate.

(cherry picked from commit 9ec134996a1162de0d74ef915dc138bbacbcfdf1)

This is the 2nd commit message:

Migrating from ostestr to stestr is also done while updating tox.ini.
Here is the ML post for more information about os-testr and stestr:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122135.html

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3

Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

NOTE(elod.illes): Here also taken only one small specific fix from this
given change since we don't need the other changes for stable/pike to
fix the gate.

(cherry picked from commit 8ce9d735d25d209a747b8f29c614236b74f95591)

Change-Id: I77b9f126ae5d500ff7fc7252b9acfed1c21f7db4
"}]
commit_message:
Add .stestr.conf to fix tox-py27 stable job

NOTE(elod.illes): This is a squash of two commit, but only .stestr.conf
and .gitignore is used from them.

os-testr 1.0.0 was introduced [1] on stable/pike, which causes tox-py27
job failure. The root cause of the problem is a bug, which has a fix[2]
but not part of os-testr 1.0.0 release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/563394/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/503877/

The first commit's message is:

The os-testr 1.0.0 release had a couple of required config changes due
to it's internal usage of stestr.

This change to stestr changed the way tests were discovered by
os-testr and as a result the unit test run was picking up tempest
tests.

NOTE(elod.illes): This is only taking one specific fix from the large
change on master since we don't need the other changes for stable/pike
to fix the gate.

(cherry picked from commit 9ec134996a1162de0d74ef915dc138bbacbcfdf1)

This is the 2nd commit message:

Migrating from ostestr to stestr is also done while updating tox.ini.
Here is the ML post for more information about os-testr and stestr:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122135.html

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3

Signed-off-by: Zhao Chao <zhaochao1984@gmail.com>

NOTE(elod.illes): Here also taken only one small specific fix from this
given change since we don't need the other changes for stable/pike to
fix the gate.

(cherry picked from commit 8ce9d735d25d209a747b8f29c614236b74f95591)

Change-Id: I77b9f126ae5d500ff7fc7252b9acfed1c21f7db4

subject: TripleO newton release
messages:
[{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-05-23 04:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-05-26 02:15:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-05-31 18:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-01 00:38:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

TripleO is kinda the pioneer of longer maintenance cycles so for right now I think it's be okay to add:

 stable-status: maintained

to all of the tripleo newton deliverables and then release from there.  Having said that Doug will know better if the publish/tag jobs will still work on newton.


the -1 is because of the typo trying to retag 5.3.9 for instack-undercloud"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-01 14:20:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > TripleO is kinda the pioneer of longer maintenance cycles so for
 > right now I think it's be okay to add:
 > 
 > stable-status: maintained
 > 
 > to all of the tripleo newton deliverables and then release from
 > there.  Having said that Doug will know better if the publish/tag
 > jobs will still work on newton.

Newton is marked as closed in the release script:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/roles/copy-release-tools-scripts/files/release-tools/process_release_requests.py#n43

For this one set of tags it will be easier to run the tool by hand, since I can modify my local copy to allow newton. Before I do that, I want to make sure that there isn't some other step we need to take first.

 > 
 > 
 > the -1 is because of the typo trying to retag 5.3.9 for
 > instack-undercloud"}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-04 03:17:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Newton is marked as closed in the release script:
 > 
 > http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/roles/copy-release-tools-scripts/files/release-tools/process_release_requests.py#n43
 > 
 > For this one set of tags it will be easier to run the tool by hand,
 > since I can modify my local copy to allow newton. Before I do that,
 > I want to make sure that there isn't some other step we need to
 > take first.

Okay sounds good."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-09 06:01:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

what are the next steps so we can EOL Newton?'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-13 21:01:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-06-13 23:42:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

As per the conversation on IRC[1] I think we're ready to process this manually and then merge this more as a history import than a change to make releases.  Once that's done we can tag all the tripleo repos as newton-eol, which I'll send via the mailing list for transparency and fact checking).  I feel like this is okay given that newton is in many senses a transitional branch from the old stable policy to the new EM policy

This does however bring up a tangential issue that IIUC Tripleo would like to take the Ocata branches directly from maintained -> EOL in the near future without going through the 6 months extended maintenance phase.  Currently this isn't called out as valid in the policy so we'll need to update the policy to reflect that.


[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-release/%23openstack-release.2018-06-13.log.html#t2018-06-13T20:47:16"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-14 13:56:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck the release has been tagged by hand'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-14 15:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-14 17:53:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

thanks!'}, {'account_id': 17499, 'date': '2018-06-15 06:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-18 13:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Include TC E-mail addresses in roster

Track each current TC member's E-mail address next to their name and
IRC nick in the members roster and include it in the rendering on
the governance site, to make them easier for community members to
figure out how to contact in private when needed. We've included TC
candidate contact E-mail addresses in the elections repository for
many cycles, but not recorded them in governance once elected. The
addresses themselves are far from secret and are already "published"
in our election results records, so there's little to be gained by
omitting them from governance.

Change-Id: If7c22f056d33e874b606c48d86d1e4236eae8a99

commit_message:
Include PTL E-mail address in rendered team pages

Display each current PTL's tracked E-mail address next to their name
and IRC nick. We've been tracking PTL contact E-mail addresses in
the governance repository for many cycles, but not presenting them
on the rendered
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/projects/<team>.html team detail
pages. The addresses themselves are far from secret and are already
"published" in the YAML version of our projects list, so there's
little to be gained by obscuring them from/in the HTML version.

Change-Id: I55d0ea058f645e8ba91cfc186eee00488ddbedcb
Story: #2001923
Task: #14450

[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-05-29 13:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It might be good to state that comments are fine to be left for nitpicks, but that should not be the basis for downvotes.'}, {'account_id': 16282, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:06:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I like the wording, but I'm in agreement might want to clarify that nitpick comments should be acceptable but should not be the only basis for a down vote or blocking the patch from landing."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:13:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm in complete and total agreement, although I didn't want to explicitly call out behaviors of downvoting and wanted to focus on encouraging positive behavior. Perhaps being explicit as such is what is needed to begin shifting the culture a little?"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:19:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

Loving it -- but let's wait to see how the ML discussion goes.

We could also list no-nitpicking examples / guidelines on a wiki page, if we expect that list/guidance to grow."}, {'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:25:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 14:32:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This looks good, thanks Julia."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:05:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:07:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:12:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2018-05-29 15:34:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Thanks for writing this up Julia.'}, {'account_id': 16465, 'date': '2018-05-29 16:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-29 17:06:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We've tried to phrase the other principles in positive terms ("we do X" or "we believe Y"rather than "we do not do Z"). How can we phrase this new item in a similar way?'}, {'account_id': 25089, 'date': '2018-05-29 18:32:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-29 18:52:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for kicking this off Julia, I think it's a really important initiative to try to harmonise our code review culture across the various subprojects, learning from those that have had success in making contributors feel welcome.

A thought I had while reading this is that it's bordering on too detailed for a statement of principles, but arguably not as detailed as it could be in terms of suggesting techniques that reviewers can use to be more welcoming. I wonder if this could be even more effective if it were split into:

* An addition to the principles phrased, as Doug suggested, in positive terms, saying that we value friendliness to contributors, especially new contributors; use processes like code review and specs to communicate and educate, not to block other people's work; default to accepting contributions and improving them, not to rejecting anything less than perfection; &c. and link through to...
* A section in the contributor guide on how (and how not) to do code review, aimed at both new and established reviewers, including specific techniques that reviewers can use to educate contributors without being unfriendly or obstructionist. We've collected quite a lot of wisdom on that subject both on the mailing list and in in-person discussions over time.

/me employs the +0-and-comment strategy"}, {'account_id': 18242, 'date': '2018-05-29 18:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-05-29 19:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-05-30 01:39:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

overall looks good. 
But i feel we should mention explicitly about this nitpick principle is for code patches only not for doc/remo ?'}, {'account_id': 19779, 'date': '2018-05-30 06:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-05-30 07:49:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm in favor of framing it more positively as Zane and Doug suggested. It seems clear from the discussion here and on the mailing list that we might not all agree on precise definitions or protocol, but the key is communication and kindness."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-30 10:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

In the ML thread there still seems to be confusion whether this encourages the posting of a new patchset over the existing change, or a new separate follow-up change, so I suggested a wording change inline.

Disclaimer: this is not nitpicking, since words are the code of resolutions :)'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2018-05-30 10:36:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-05-30 12:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:01:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

So if I don't -1 and I don't +1 but I have a comment, will my comment go unnoticed?"}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:06:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't pay much attention to the TC guidelines etc (I apologize). I was wondering whether this belonged in the principles page, or more as a guidelines thing. Do we consider this a main principle of being part of OpenStack? I guess what I'd like to see is more of what has been mentioned in the email thread; I feel like 2 paragraphs doesn't adequately capture the pros/cons/issues. But maybe that's the same thing with all the other principles here. And the reason why I'm pondering this is that proposing a followup isn't the only way to address nits, and it seems useful to me to present the other alternatives."}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-05-30 14:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-30 16:52:02.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-05-30 16:54:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
