In case anybody missed it on the mailing list, we're also working on documenting in the contributor guide specific techniques to use in code reviews as a complement to this change:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-June/131085.html"}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-06-04 18:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I do not have specific line to target this but more against the whole idea. I can't speak for all the projects but I can say that at least looking things in Glance perspective it would be way more counter productive insisting follow-up patch rather than getting the problems fixed in first place.

Obviously we do follow-ups as well, specially in two cases ... the gate is misbehaving and that new revision might be the trigger for next 20 rechecks or if the minor change is needed somewhere in the beginning of the change chain and would cause rebase hell. Most of the time we do defer merging anyways until the follow-up is available (as we have noticed those follow-ups not happening otherwise.)

Now the big thing is how to define nit ... I don't think we do block or down vote on what is considered as nitpicking, we do as I know lots of other people as well flag those things when we do know that there is new revision needed for real reasons as in "While you fix A and B, would you mind to reword this as well to make it clearer". Also I'm not interested to see follow-up patches and having to review them if it was only nitpick worthy in the first place. Actually we have section specifically asking not to do these in our contribution guidelines https://docs.openstack.org/glance/queens/contributor/minor-code-changes.html

I'm not native English speaker and I'm happy to have people correcting my doc changes etc. as long as the rewording doesn't change the intention of that piece of text to something it should not be stating. I'd also be way happier having a good bug description rather than poor patch with expectation that I should be approving that patch just as a courtesy for the person who bothered write it but doesn't bother to address the reviews. Or even better I'd have nothing against functionally working patch that needs some tuning with the comment from original author in lines of "Feel free to take this over as this is how far I have cycles to work on it".

It's bit like expecting us to force changes through the gate that fails PEP8 tests just because the person doesn't know PEP8 and tbh all of those are just nitpicking ;) Also lots of "nitpicking" is consistency related which is one of the corner stones of PEP8 and something that is really difficult to enforce by automated testing.

Perhaps better option would be just start calling out those nitpickers and change their behaviour within the community than write some principle that would give and idea that we will by definition accept what ever you throw at us and fix it some day just to be friendly.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-05 07:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2018-06-06 02:48:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2018-06-06 02:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-06 09:48:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-06-06 09:59:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Shameless side note: I've been thinking about the psychological part of the code review process which (in my experience) sometimes gets in the way [1]. Sharing my thoughts here just in case someone finds them useful for setting up the context for the ongoing discussion...

1. https://access.redhat.com/blogs/766093/posts/2802001"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-11 23:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I do not have specific line to target this but more against the
 > whole idea. I can't speak for all the projects but I can say that
 > at least looking things in Glance perspective it would be way more
 > counter productive insisting follow-up patch rather than getting
 > the problems fixed in first place.

It all comes down to what we define as problems. Some of the minor code changes that you linked to in your reply have been along the lines that I've seen cores block patches for in projects. The tests pass, but they want them in a very specific way. Having to update that patch multiple times because they want the tests in their favorite style is not productive, espescialy when it then effectively blocks additional reviews if the change is downvoted.

 >  Most of
 > the time we do defer merging anyways until the follow-up is
 > available (as we have noticed those follow-ups not happening
 > otherwise.)

From an ironic POV, We do the same, but we also have a tendency to have large feature sets lined up in multiple patches as they are typically spread across 4-8 patch sets to begin with. I would be afraid of the costs if we had numbers for that. :(

 > Now the big thing is how to define nit ... I don't think we do
 > block or down vote on what is considered as nitpicking, we do as I
 > know lots of other people as well flag those things when we do know
 > that there is new revision needed for real reasons as in "While you
 > fix A and B, would you mind to reword this as well to make it
 > clearer". Also I'm not interested to see follow-up patches and
 > having to review them if it was only nitpick worthy in the first
 > place. Actually we have section specifically asking not to do these
 > in our contribution guidelines https://docs.openstack.org/glance/queens/contributor/minor-code-changes.html
 > 

Much of the feedback I've gotten has either been "call out the negative behaviors" or "call out the behaviors we want, and not detail the negative behaviors. I think it is great that a team has sat down and written specific guidelines for minor code changes, but at the same time I think prohibiting minor iterative improvement is not something the community wants. I would personally rather see a 2-3 line patch to fix some minor items rather than have to review 200-300 lines again. 

 > I'm not native English speaker and I'm happy to have people
 > correcting my doc changes etc. as long as the rewording doesn't
 > change the intention of that piece of text to something it should
 > not be stating. I'd also be way happier having a good bug
 > description rather than poor patch with expectation that I should
 > be approving that patch just as a courtesy for the person who
 > bothered write it but doesn't bother to address the reviews. Or
 > even better I'd have nothing against functionally working patch
 > that needs some tuning with the comment from original author in
 > lines of "Feel free to take this over as this is how far I have
 > cycles to work on it".

Sadly, the preference for contributors seems to vary. I'm unsure of a way to help reduce some of the friction that occurs there, even with explicit "hey, take this over" communication. I also feel that it might be out of scope of the TC's desire to reduce the amount of nitpicking.

 > It's bit like expecting us to force changes through the gate that
 > fails PEP8 tests just because the person doesn't know PEP8 and tbh
 > all of those are just nitpicking ;) Also lots of "nitpicking" is
 > consistency related which is one of the corner stones of PEP8 and
 > something that is really difficult to enforce by automated testing.

I don't think it is just consistency related, but cases where there is a lack of understanding, or the desire for there to only be polished perfection merged into a project's code base. Having experienced nitpicking more times than I would like... well.. it is frustrating and does burn contributors out.

 > Perhaps better option would be just start calling out those
 > nitpickers and change their behaviour within the community than
 > write some principle that would give and idea that we will by
 > definition accept what ever you throw at us and fix it some day
 > just to be friendly.

I think we can have consensus on calling out nitpickers and their behavior, but we absolutely have to have our principles written down in that regards in order to help facilitate not just a dialog, but a mutual understanding. Although if your perception is that we're wanting every old patch or change to be accepted, then that is absolutely not what we're trying to do.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-11 23:51:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

New revision in-bound in the morning.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-12 13:04:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15993, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:34:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I really like how this reads! My only question is on the last sentence are we saying the reviewer makes the change, the patch author or both? And this is more for my personal clarification unless others have the same question in which case we clarify the text.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> I really like how this reads! My only question is on the last
 > sentence are we saying the reviewer makes the change, the patch
 > author or both? And this is more for my personal clarification
 > unless others have the same question in which case we clarify the
 > text.

From my point of view, the answer is yes. The goal is to get people to talk, and then kind of work out how they go from there. Each project is going to be different, each subgroup in a project may also be different, so the only way to kind of resolve those differences and set mutual expectations is to talk.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-12 16:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Add principles entry for peer review

During numerous discussions at the Vancouver 2018 Forum,
the topic of discouraging review cultural behaviors came
up repeatedly.

This has come up before, but never to the point where prior
community participants and leaders who took the opportunity
to reconnect with the community came into the room and
explicitly stated that it was the review culture as to
why they left.

The common frustration that was repeatedly raised was having
to revise patches over and over due to varying nitpicks where
negative feedback was left forcing the patch to be updated
in order to gain any additional review feedback.

We recognize that this is counter productive, and that we
need to change our review culture, so we are updating the
principles to express the aspects of peer review that we
value.

Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Change-Id: I3b615784824de2a15a911780fe8c37928f2c453e

commit_message:
Re-using the code of os brick cinder

To avoid the errors during force delete of logical volume,
cinder library os brick is already using udevadm settle for it.
Calling the same library of cinder in nova too.

Change-Id: I092afdd0409ab27187cf74cd1514e9e0c550d52c
Closes-Bug: #1191960

commit_message:
Create L3 start/stop scripts for minor updates.

Scripts for managin ping-test for P are missing from undercloud,
 preventing checking FIP's reachability during minor update.
Also create scripts for detectin L3 agent failover.

Change-Id: I5ea08e59b544fe242d335bd7546addd6130fc591

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We can't set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36 due to https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/425

Change-Id: I9eca1cc89f809a219636278bb72b65d61657db75

commit_message:
Add trusted certs to feature support matrix docs

Even though the feature is technically virt driver agnostic,
the plumbing happens through the virt drivers, so the feature
is only supported by certain virt drivers (libvirt only at
the time of this patch). So this adds a section to the feature
support matrix about the trusted certs validation feature.

Also updates the certificate validation user docs based on
the nova boot --trusted-image-certificate-id option name
in the dependent python-novaclient change.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/500396/

Related to blueprint nova-validate-certificates

commit_message:
Write tempest-multinode-full as zuulv3 native

Rewrite the base tempest multinode job as zuulv3.
The job is currently hosted in the neutron repo as
neutron-tempest-multinode-full.

Full job name history:
* neutron-tempest-multinode-full
* legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multinode-full
* gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-multinode-full-ubuntu-xenial-nv

With this patch, devstack-tempest can be used as a basis for both
single and multinode jobs.

Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/561187
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/561251
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/564220
Depends-on: https://review.openstack.org/572313

Change-Id: If448ae20bca6e221b4a10646c69ba014656438ad

subject: Update to upstream
messages:
[{'account_id': 19224, 'date': '2018-04-10 09:35:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-04-23 14:27:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 19224, 'date': '2018-04-26 03:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Link from CDNJS only need js and css, for png files and map files are also automatically linked. If used these files as local library, we need more to avoid 404 errors. I just choose to include necessary files here, maybe I should include all files in the upstream repo.'}, {'account_id': 19224, 'date': '2018-04-26 03:18:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

4.3.0 distribution files are described in the following link (in dist folder)
https://github.com/almende/vis/archive/v4.3.0.zip'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-04-27 04:54:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks. I don't have a strong opinion on this, but it is better to be documented somewhere. Could you add some notes in the repo?"}, {'account_id': 19224, 'date': '2018-04-27 10:02:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-04-30 15:30:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I don't want to be an only reviewer to xstatic repos.

xstatic-cores,
When you feel the proposed README.rst has enough information to maintain the xstatic-vis repo even if the current active folks have gone from the project, put +2. Otherwise, leave some comments on the current proposed version.

I will revisit this after enough feedbacks from other xstatic-cores."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-05-07 20:01:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm not sure that we're OK to add minified js and css files to the repo. How will it work with 'django compress'?"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-05-07 22:04:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

we consider minified JavaScripts as non-free [1], so they are not acceptable. Including minified JS files re-introduce the original discussion around heat-dashboard queens release again. It should be avoided.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/topics/packaging.html#minified-javascript-policy'}, {'account_id': 19224, 'date': '2018-05-08 07:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-06-05 14:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-06-18 12:32:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Use coordination to prevent duplicate pricing

Use MySQL as coordination backend for cloudkitty-processors.
Otherwise prices may get calculated multiple times.

Change-Id: I0ba5a1a362322f5e25d3ef3795287c34140b2330
Closes-Bug: 1777432

I'm still doing some tests, I want to merge after the 15th"}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:58:44.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Alessandro Nesta <huang.zhiping@99cloud.net>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-09 16:21:06.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ice90430a7421fd3bf5e7991d81fa0928393354c3
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ice90430a7421fd3bf5e7991d81fa0928393354c3

to run TripleO Validations on the undercloud.

commit_message:
undercloud: deploy tripleo-validations when needed

When enabled, deploy tripleo-validations service to have parity with
instack-undercloud. It'll run Puppet and install the rpm + user useful
to run TripleO Validations on the undercloud.

Depends-On: Ida09f92010e31d952edd82b42a7fc20451537d42
Change-Id: Id6822ee8297943145865fc468d9c7a7c8fbb64c0

commit_message:
Implement TripleoValidations composable service

Implement a service that will deploy TripleO Validations package and
user by using Puppet like we did with instack-undercloud. This service
will be included on the undercloud but disabled by default. We'll keep
the same interface in undercloud.conf to enable it or not so no change
for the end user.

Change-Id: Ida09f92010e31d952edd82b42a7fc20451537d42

commit_message:
Fix _cls_registry type

Horizon commit e50a69d69f338d0ec66baa659a7d82e328e62a67 saw
_cls_registry become a list instead of a set. We need to reflect this
change, or else see:
  'set' object has no attribute 'append'

Change-Id: I302b6120145909fc4d342579818b05584a0820a3

Something similar is already implemented. Is it what you have in mind?

$ vbmc -h
usage: Virtual BMC admin tool [-h] [--version] [--no-daemon]
                              {add,delete,start,stop,list,show} ...

A virtual BMC for controlling virtual instances

positional arguments:
  {add,delete,start,stop,list,show}
    add                 Add a new virtual BMC
    delete              Delete a virtual BMC
    start               Start a virtual BMC
    stop                Stop a virtual BMC
    list                list all virtual BMCs
    show                Show a virtual BMC

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-28 21:52:09.000000000', 'message': "WIP: threading server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/watch free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way admin communication with the vBMC instances
  what makes state check difficult

This commit attempts to turn server part of the tool into
a single process running multiple threads:

* one thread per vBMC instance
* main thread handling admin interface

The main thread is able to:

* manipulate permanent instance configuration
* spawn and tear down instances threads

Naturally, all threads die together so it's easy to manage
them all at once.

The main challenge with the new design so far is to
shutdown IPMI session clearly. Thus, WIP.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
"}, {'created': '2017-07-31 13:19:50.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

'}, {'created': '2017-08-01 16:43:03.000000000', 'message': "WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool behaviour. Whenever
it can't connect to the `vbmcd` it tries to fork and spawn
the daemon.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
"}, {'created': '2017-08-02 12:57:25.000000000', 'message': "WIP: multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via admin cli), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via admin cli). The instances become
independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain usage inconveniences with the original
design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC.

The parent process runs admin interface, maintains
persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
dies, it tries its best to kill all its orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
Also, having multiple processes leverages CPU-based
concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

"}, {'created': '2017-08-02 15:53:01.000000000', 'message': "multiprocess server, socket-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via the cli tool). Then the instances
become independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via IPC (the multiprocessing module does that).

The parent process runs server part of the control interface,
maintains persistent vBMC instances configuration and ensures
all its children are alive and kicking. Each vBMC
instance is still a separate parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideraton is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d

"}, {'created': '2018-03-20 08:07:56.000000000', 'message': "multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool

Original design of the vBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual vBMCs (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual vBMCs (via the cli tool). Then the instances
become independent processes. The only way to know their
whereabouts is through the pidfiles they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the vBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via ZMQ client/server.

The parent process runs server part of the control
interface, maintains persistent vBMC instances
configuration and ensures all its children are alive
and kicking. Each vBMC instance is still a separate
parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Other changes:

* The `start` command now accepts more than one domains
  to be started

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
Closes-Bug: #1751570

commit_message:
multiprocess server, ZMQ-based management cli tool

Original design of the VirtualBMC tool was that user manages
config files for individual VirtualBMC (via a cli tool), then
requests the tool to start the instances representing
individual VirtualBMC instances (via the cli tool). Then
the instances become independent processes. The only way
to know their whereabouts is through the pidfiles
they maintain.

There were certain practical inconveniences with the
original design, namely:

* Cumbersome to start/stop/monitor free-standing
  vBMC instances processes
* No two-way communication between the parent process
  and the VirtualBMC instances what makes child state check
  or modification unnecessary difficult

This commit turns server part of the tool into a single
process spawning multiple children processes and herding
them via ZMQ client/server.

The parent process runs server part of the control
interface, maintains persistent VirtualBMC instances
configuration and ensures all its children are alive
and kicking. Each VirtualBMC instance is still a separate
parent fork.

If child dies, parent respawns it right away. If parent
is about to die, it tries its best to kill all the
prospective orphans.

This new implementation tries to stay compatible with
the original one in part of `vbmc` tool CLI interface
and behaviour. Whenever it can't connect to the `vbmcd`
it tries to fork and spawn the daemon behind the scenes.

While the threading design for this tool might look better,
the underlying pyghmi library is apparently rather
complicated to use its concurrency capabilities reliably.
The other minor consideration is that running multiple
processes leverages CPU-based concurrency.

Other changes:

* The `start` command now accepts more than one domains
  to be started

Change-Id: Ie10f4598c7039a7afa9b45d01df3b3c3db252c1d
Story: 1751570
Task:  12057

messages: [{'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-06-09 03:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-06-11 06:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-06-11 15:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-06-15 16:04:50.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Alessandro Nesta <huang.zhiping@99cloud.net>\n'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-06-18 11:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-09 03:11:13.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I5db260ef3cdd09a5cf6b87733db34b5ad830deab
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I5db260ef3cdd09a5cf6b87733db34b5ad830deab

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-11 13:47:33.000000000', 'message': 'rerun *_init_bundles all the time

In the same spirit as change I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
we want to rerun all pacemaker _init_bundles all the time. For a few main
reasons:
1) We will eventually support scaling-up roles that contain
   pacemaker-managed services and we need to rerun _init_bundles so that
   pacemaker properties are created for the newly added nodes.
2) When you replace a controller the pacemaker properties will be
   recreated for the newly added node.
3) We need to create appropriate iptables rules whenever we add a
   service to an existing deployment.

We do this by adding the DeployIdentifier to the environment so that
paunch will retrigger a run at every redeploy.

Partial-Bug: #1775196
Change-Id: Ifd48d74507609fc7f4abc269b61b2868bfbc9272
(cherry picked from commit a0dfc6c0c694091eae195d4090a63e339f3daa39)

commit_message:
rerun *_init_bundles all the time

In the same spirit as change I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
we want to rerun all pacemaker _init_bundles all the time. For a few main
reasons:
1) We will eventually support scaling-up roles that contain
   pacemaker-managed services and we need to rerun _init_bundles so that
   pacemaker properties are created for the newly added nodes.
2) When you replace a controller the pacemaker properties will be
   recreated for the newly added node.
3) We need to create appropriate iptables rules whenever we add a
   service to an existing deployment.

We do this by adding the DeployIdentifier to the environment so that
paunch will retrigger a run at every redeploy.

Partial-Bug: #1775196
Change-Id: Ifd48d74507609fc7f4abc269b61b2868bfbc9272
(cherry picked from commit a0dfc6c0c694091eae195d4090a63e339f3daa39)

subject: replace windows line endings with unix line endings
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-13 18:34:51.000000000', 'message': 'replace windows line endings with unix line endings

The python 3 version of the linter does not allow Windows-style line
endings (\r\n) so replace them with UNIX-style endings (\n).

Change-Id: Ifb97491323d3df92bb1520e373552aeb5e1919a4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
replace windows line endings with unix line endings

The python 3 version of the linter does not allow Windows-style line
endings (\r\n) so replace them with UNIX-style endings (\n).

Change-Id: Ifb97491323d3df92bb1520e373552aeb5e1919a4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

- ironic-coverage-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/44/509844/1/check/ironic-coverage-ubuntu-xenial/8d19f15/ : SUCCESS in 7m 17s'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2017-10-06 08:08:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sam this is really nice work thanks for doing it.
Current enrollment model is not flexible enough to be able to enroll nodes with different capabilities in the same setup. Due to this we always increase number of our jobs. I was thinking about rewriting it completely to something that provides such flexibility.
I think our big mistake that we using global vars to specify characteristics of the nodes as result all nodes will be the same. Instead of doing this we may define nodes in yml format (the same as supported by `openstack baremetal create` command) which defines a nodes we would like to enroll, and based on that data our simulator will create a setup. what do you think?'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2017-10-06 11:09:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Make Ironic devstack simulation less dependent on OVS

The VM simulation is heavily tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

This patch adds additional configuration steps that mean that we can now
run neutron in either LB or OVS modes with out affecting the simulation.

Change-Id: I0a7cf018cd0cf7463fa361a1fb6f6fc79a49c1f0

commit_message:
Handle multinode VXLAN tunnel inside ironic devstack plugin

For our devstack plugin to work out of the box for multinode we should
handle the configuration of the VXLAN tunnel between the nodes in our
devstack plugin instead of in devstack-gate.

Change-Id: I04172200464abc4e486ae85a655176bf230d953e

commit_message:
Grenade source correct Ironic devstack plugin version

This patch ensures that we source the Ironic devstack plugin from the
version of devstack that was used to setup the devstack environment
preventing any future changes to the devstack plugin from breaking the
upgrade process.

Change-Id: I7b017827fb0bf3f7bddd92d469955c739eae6d30

(6 comments)

Sam thanks for the patch, this is really big and needed change, I think we should split it to smaller ones. Technically it is possible to have mixed environment with flat and neutron network interface nodes in one setup so I would suggest to have separate variables for FLAT and PROVISION networks.

What do you think about the following steps:

1. Replace current VXLAN network by real Neutron FLAT network. IRONIC_NODE_NETWORK_INTERFACE may be used as a trigger to specify which network to setup for now.

2. Use conductor IPs from FLAT/PROVISION network for deployment (TFTP, HTTP) instead of HOST_IP.

3. Allow to use Neutron in LB mode (still connect ironic nodes to OVS)

4. Add possibility to connect ironic nodes to LB directly.'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-12-01 11:09:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow-1

(6 comments)

I'll investigate splitting this patch down into smaller pieces, however its such a dramatic change many of the pieces a tied together.

I don't need to split the variables because the way the simulation is configured can support both nodes configured with "flat" and with "neutron" network interfaces configured out of the box. If you switch the IRONIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK_TYPE to vlan, then it'll just work.'}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2016-12-01 11:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)

> (6 comments)
 > 
 > I'll investigate splitting this patch down into smaller pieces,
 > however its such a dramatic change many of the pieces a tied
 > together.
 > 
 > I don't need to split the variables because the way the simulation
 > is configured can support both nodes configured with "flat" and
 > with "neutron" network interfaces configured out of the box. If you
 > switch the IRONIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK_TYPE to vlan, then it'll just
 > work.

But it is possible to configure only one network in Neutron flat or vlan in the same setup I just want to allow mixing nodes with flat and with vlan network in same setup.'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-12-01 11:50:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6637, 'date': '2016-12-01 12:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > > (6 comments)
 > >
 > > I'll investigate splitting this patch down into smaller pieces,
 > > however its such a dramatic change many of the pieces a tied
 > > together.
 > >
 > > I don't need to split the variables because the way the
 > simulation
 > > is configured can support both nodes configured with "flat" and
 > > with "neutron" network interfaces configured out of the box. If
 > you
 > > switch the IRONIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK_TYPE to vlan, then it'll just
 > > work.
 > 
 > But it is possible to configure only one network in Neutron flat or
 > vlan in the same setup I just want to allow mixing nodes with flat
 > and with vlan network in same setup.

So unfortunately we called the "flat" network interface, "flat" IMO I've discovered that badly describes the interface, we should really rename it to "static" or something along those lines. Whether it is an untagged "flat" network or a vlan network with statically configured switches, it doesn't matter, the "flat" network interface works.'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2016-12-01 15:50:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-02 20:38:52.000000000', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

For a visual representation of an example topology that would exist in
this simulated environment look here: https://goo.gl/Ab0e3R

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added. The variables that exist for
tweaking simulated network configuration should be reusable to enhance
our devstack plugin's support for real hardware scenarios.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac

"}, {'created': '2016-11-08 20:22:18.000000000', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

For a visual representation of an example topology that would exist in
this simulated environment look here: https://goo.gl/Ab0e3R

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac

"}, {'created': '2017-01-18 11:48:22.000000000', 'message': "Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The existing logic is heavily
tied to the neutron deployment using OVS.

The new logic isolates the simulated network, using linux bridge and
vEth devices, letting neutron treat it like a real physical network.
This means that we can now run neutron in either LB or OVS modes and it
doesn't affect our simulation.

Additionally we can now simulate a statically configured VLAN network,
as an alternative to a flat network. With some additional changes in
networking-generic-switch multiple isolated tenant networks will be
supported.

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

New development documentation has been added to describe why and how we
create a simulated baremetal environment.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac
Depends-On: I7790cd6750630d6bb8ffbe9ca1eb066760d06475
Depends-On: I6475788aa230bbdb048425d9c1b51404d59a1bef
Depends-On: I560dc41106b16dc1a19ae80248af82b552c96358

commit_message:
Rework Ironic devstack baremetal network simulation

This patch replaces the existing devstack logic for simulating virtual
baremetals attached to a virtual network. The new logic isolates the
simulated environment from the neutron deployment so that the simulation
appears as a physical network to Neutron.

This change also makes the devstack ironic neutron configuration work
for cases when IRONIC_IS_HARDWARE=True, configuring real interfaces for
use with the neutron networks.

In order to make this work several old ironic devstack variables have
been removed, and a few new ones added.

New development documentation has been added to describe why and how we
create a simulated baremetal environment.

Change-Id: I7384f026d845f07bcd421f68f6b806fd64cd95ac
Depends-On: I6475788aa230bbdb048425d9c1b51404d59a1bef
Depends-On: I560dc41106b16dc1a19ae80248af82b552c96358

commit_message:
[WIP][DNM] Experiment with batch through iptables-restore

Instead of making hundreds of requests to iptables, we can use
iptables-restore to batch load new rules into iptables.

Change-Id: Icfa268654347f4405d53504065847c6fda57a6e6

commit_message:
DNM: Validate I677afef96370ead5a45cba854ba483f18a8d1247

We want to make sure the aforementioned commit won't break jobs
unnecessarily. Do this by purposefully breaking the build and then
testing a variety of configurations:

commit_message:
Correcting url in action_plan policy

url in action_plan policy file is:
'path': '/v1/action_plans/{action_plan_uuid}/action'
whereas it shouls be :
'path': '/v1/action_plans/{action_plan_uuid}/start'

Related-Bug: #1756274

Change-Id: Ic15fed9af739b59efb2777b70514697747b2af7f

subject: Allow config_template to be loaded as a role
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-17 19:36:48.000000000', 'message': 'Allow config_template to be loaded as a role

Currently when this repo loaded as a role instead of copied to
plugins paths, config_template tasks fail because:
FAILED! => {"msg": "module (config_template) is missing interpreter line"}

This is because ansible searches for action plugins in the action_plugins/
path of roles and plays instead of action/. See
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/plugins/action.html#enabling-action-plugins
for information on this.

By simply symlinking action_plugins -> action we can make this work
in either scenario.

Change-Id: I59625e358e220b83d4a2580ac5f99bc11751ebdd
'}]
commit_message:
Allow config_template to be loaded as a role

Currently when this repo loaded as a role instead of copied to
plugins paths, config_template tasks fail because:
FAILED! => {"msg": "module (config_template) is missing interpreter line"}

This is because ansible searches for action plugins in the action_plugins/
path of roles and plays instead of action/. See
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/plugins/action.html#enabling-action-plugins
for information on this.

By simply symlinking action_plugins -> action we can make this work
in either scenario.

Change-Id: I59625e358e220b83d4a2580ac5f99bc11751ebdd

commit_message:
Doc: Remove -r option for running a specific unit test

Now that os-testr was replaced with stestr for running unit tests, -r
options is no longer necessary to pass a regex to the test runner.

Change-Id: I2d3738e3af47a4a01db3223941e07e68537b5a5c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-08 18:19:23.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3c8e5c663a3fd881430f84fc502e46192de77fc7
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3c8e5c663a3fd881430f84fc502e46192de77fc7

commit_message:
Prometheus datasource

The datasource currently supports notifications from
Prometheus.

There are a few related tasks that will be handled in
future commits:

1. Prometheus may send the ip of the instance instead
   of its name. We need to find a way (in the
   transformer)to identify the correct instance in
   the graph.

2. The 'vitrage event post' API should be changed so
   it can handle events from Prometheus.

3. Need to implement get_all in the datasource

Change-Id: Id1cba3e060b70c232891a34bf6793c185a074a7b
Depends-On: Ide6906ee477aa7df9ab0918d3b45a7001afdcf74
Implements: blueprint prometheus-datasource

commit_message:
undercloud: manage mysql user + revoke grant during upgrade

This task is done when bootstraping a new deployment but we also need to
run these commands when upgrading the containerized undercloud so
healthcheck can run mysql commands from mysql user.

Change-Id: Ie77785caba0a1fb8e2058a998b21cc88bc666fd7
Closes-Bug: #1776570

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-06-13 01:51:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-06-13 02:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Published edit on patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-06-13 02:52:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-06-13 10:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-13 11:06:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

Sorry if this has already been discussed, but what if someone already has roles 'member' and 'reader' in their deployment, without one implying the other, and for the sake of argument has already crafted specific policy rules for each role - then after running this bootstrap command, which should be idempotent, now suddenly has an implied relationship between their two preexisting roles? Won't that break their policies?"}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-06-13 11:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15699, 'date': '2018-06-13 11:34:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-13 11:45:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-06-13 13:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Coleen:  In the case that you state, it will provide access to the *reader* protected APIs that *member* did not have.  However, one reason that we chose *reader* instead of *auditor* is that *auditor* implies a wider access.  Note that a *member* would still be limited only to operations within the same scope--project for the most part.  I think we are OK here.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-06-13 13:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

> Coleen:  In the case that you state, it will provide access to the
 > *reader* protected APIs that *member* did not have.  However, one
 > reason that we chose *reader* instead of *auditor* is that
 > *auditor* implies a wider access.  Note that a *member* would still
 > be limited only to operations within the same scope--project for
 > the most part.  I think we are OK here.

Okay, I think I'm happier with this answer than I am with the IRC discussion about bootstrap not being idempotent. If we're considering this an acceptable risk based on the chosen names of the roles then at least that should highlighted in the release notes by making a note in the "upgrade" section.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-06-13 17:05:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Published edit on patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 11589, 'date': '2018-06-13 18:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-06-13 18:29:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

[{'created': '2018-06-05 02:26:12.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Ensure default roles created during bootstrap

Expand bootstrap process to include creation of roles outlined in
basic default roles spec[1].

Change-Id: Ie18a269e3d1075d955fe494acaf634a393c6bd7b
'}, {'created': '2018-06-05 09:37:12.000000000', 'message': "Ensure default roles created during bootstrap

Expand bootstrap process to include creation of roles outlined in
basic default roles spec.

This creates two more roles, besdides the 'admin' one. Namely,
'_member_' and 'reader'. It also sets 'reader' to be an implied
role for '_member_', and '_member_' as an implied role for 'admin'.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
bp define-default-roles
Change-Id: Ie18a269e3d1075d955fe494acaf634a393c6bd7b
"}, {'created': '2018-06-05 15:38:13.000000000', 'message': "Ensure default roles created during bootstrap

Expand bootstrap process to include creation of roles outlined in
basic default roles spec.

This creates two more roles, besdides the 'admin' one. Namely,
'member' and 'reader'. It also sets 'reader' to be an implied
role for 'member', and 'member' as an implied role for 'admin'.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Ensure default roles created during bootstrap

Expand bootstrap process to include creation of roles outlined in
basic default roles spec.

The bootstrap process now creates two new roles, 'reader' and 'member,
in addition to the well established 'admin' role. During this process,
a role implication[1] chain is created: 'admin' implies 'member' and
'member' implies 'reader'.

[1] - https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/#create-role-inference-rule

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
bp basic-default-roles
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/574149
Change-Id: Ie18a269e3d1075d955fe494acaf634a393c6bd7b

subject: Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory
messages:
[{'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-06-15 09:30:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-06-15 09:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This needs testing.'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-06-18 09:06:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This was an environmental issue caused by ansible 2.5.3 coming from epel.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 09:30:01.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory

It normally uses $HOME that is set to the mistral working directory
already , but for some reason it stopped working in my environment and
tries to write a directory in /home/mistral/.ansible/tmp/. The strange
thing is that there is
a /var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/.ansible/tmp/ directory too.

Change-Id: Ib18f82f6b50d114880e4fc22e716c44898cfba89
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ansible tmp dir to mistral working directory

It normally uses $HOME that is set to the mistral working directory
already , but for some reason it stopped working in my environment and
tries to write a directory in /home/mistral/.ansible/tmp/. The strange
thing is that there is
a /var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/.ansible/tmp/ directory too.

Change-Id: Ib18f82f6b50d114880e4fc22e716c44898cfba89

commit_message:
Fix the file name of development-environment.rst

In Ideb50626e140201dded19fc82584440f1a407e47,
the path of development-environment.rst has been fixed
in doc/README.rst. But the file name was not fixed.

Fix the file name of development-environment.rst
in doc/README.rst.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: I5a6df81cc18d002e9bf1c69c9b270f132edaafa3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-12 13:00:55.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that free all the resouce of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

Used for enable closing watch threads without resource leaking,
and it's needed for the netwrok-policy handler as it's adds and removes
watches for each policy CUD operation.

Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2

"}, {'created': '2018-03-26 08:10:54.000000000', 'message': "DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that frees all the resources of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

This allows to close watch threads without resource leaking.
This is required for network-policy handler that adds and
removes watches on networkpolicy events.(the watch thread 
can't dispose itself - becuase the watch could be long 
time on io-wait)



Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2
"}, {'created': '2018-03-26 09:16:23.000000000', 'message': "DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that frees all the resources of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

This allows to close watch threads without resource leaking.
This is required for network-policy handler that adds and
removes watches on networkpolicy events.The watch thread
can't dispose itself - because the watch could be long
time on io-wait.



Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2
"}, {'created': '2018-03-26 11:31:51.000000000', 'message': "DisposableWatch for k8s client

"}, {'created': '2018-04-02 13:03:11.000000000', 'message': "DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that frees all the resources of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

This allows to close watch threads without resource leaking.
This is required for network-policy handler that adds and
removes watches on networkpolicy events.The watch thread
can't dispose itself - because the watch could be long
time on io-wait.



Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2
"}]
commit_message:
DisposableWatch for k8s client

Add object that frees all the resources of the watch
(file descriptor and connection).

This allows to close watch threads without resource leaking.
This is required for network-policy handler that adds and
removes watches on networkpolicy events.The watch thread
can't dispose itself - because the watch could be long
time on io-wait.



Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: Iafcec892e5889e711905542201a214a2727a0fd2

commit_message:
Annotate pods that selected by k8s label-selector

Set a watch on each selector in the policy -
and annotate the pods with the relevant security-group.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I3d121dbfde36fe20f95648cea03c7e97f490f4c2

@Eyal: Can you please provide few samples of the k8s commands to use to verify the patch?'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-22 14:51:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@irenab -  sure 

for testing the patch copy the content of  https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/network_policy_examples into file  

for create network_policy run : 
kubectl -f apply [file_path] 

you can test for new security group by run: 
openstack security group list 

test the content of the created security group: 
openstack security group show [sg-id]

delete the policy by:
kubectl -f delete [file_path]'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-22 16:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-01-23 08:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-01-23 11:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Hi Eyal,

The overall design, handler/drivers layers looks fine.

I added also few minor syntax comments.

My main concern is the network policy edit use case, that being handled by create SGs and delete old SGs. That should trigger port-update for all relevant neutron ports.

I think you should consider keeping the same SGs in case it possible.'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-02-05 07:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-02-05 09:12:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-02-05 09:13:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Create network policy handler and driver

This patch adds watch on network policy events.
At this stage the watch will create a security-group that
corresponds to the network-policy but the security group will not
be attached to any port.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Parent:     6c86b930 (Translate k8s policy to SG)

Change-Id: I8df683da09decd8a4a4d3e58a61d71d451d2aa0d

commit_message:
Add policy security-groups driver

The driver reads the sg annotaions and updates the port respectively.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I4aa47913503c3a0e04f3067b92d11fe45f641804

(4 comments)

Hi Eyal,

I added few comments inside , mainly spelling issues.
I'm missing the context of this task, 
The role of this patch is to translate K8S-Network policy into Neutron SGs ,right ?
I assume that this driver will be called by net-policy handler.
Don't u need to add base driver definition ? 
How the handler will get the info he needs for annotations ?"}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-16 16:41:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-16 16:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-18 09:27:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-21 07:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-01-21 08:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(11 comments)

I like the split into SG creation logic and the Applier, makes it possible to reuse most of the code across SDN that provide SG API'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-01-21 13:51:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

See inline some spelling issues.

I like the idea of having another layer of abstraction (between policy handler and SG apply driver).

But I think that this layer should be under handler and not driver.
It's abstraction/simplification layer of handler.

Unlike all current kuryr drivers, the policy2sg is statefull. 
I know that this patch deals with translating net-policy to SG.

Do you plan to support update flow by 'policy2sg' or by handler ?



I think 
 From what I'm familiar with , all kuryr-drivers are singletons, just stateless translation.

From what I'm familiar with , all kuryr-drivers are singletons, just stateless translation."}, {'account_id': 26131, 'date': '2018-01-22 12:24:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(5 comments)

Hi Yossi , 
thanks for your review. 

The policy2sg should be call be the driver. 
That is the planed-flow : policy_hanlder->sg_policy_driver->policy2sg->sg-apply.

The idea behind the separation is that we have some networking backends that support the open-stack security-group format (neutron, dragonflow and maybe odl and ovn), The security-group driver create the security-groups, and the applier should apply the sg on the networking backend. If someone will want to implement network policy by different objects (For example: neutron-fwaas), a new policy driver should be written for that. 

About the stateless - also the policy-driver planned to be stateless. The translate class is not planned to be serialized. It's there in order to separate the complex of the network-policy handling to smaller building blocks (translate,watches, controller-restart-handle etc.. ). you can take a look in the first version of the driver here:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/530655/5/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/network_policy/driver.py"}, {'account_id': 14885, 'date': '2018-01-24 09:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

Depends-On: Iee6e0412dec15c259203de23e9ac7936da92d4f9 
Change-Id: I0c1b85a8a363ab42685c9922b08811f8c99bce94
'}, {'created': '2017-12-14 08:50:50.000000000', 'message': "Translate k8s policy to SG

Supporting network-policy by kuryr it's
and it's involved some works-items
(all of them specified in the blueprint)

This patch , is the first work item ,
and use for translate the ks8-network-poicy to
neutron-secuirty-groups . it's take json that describe
the network-policy , and use neutron to create the relevant
secuirty-groups.

commit_message:
Translate k8s policy to SG

This patch contains a module that translates k8s-network-policy
to neutron-security-groups. The input for this module is the
network-policy.json and it's translates it to security-groups-rules
and apply it by neutron client.

In this patch the module still not connected to any driver.

This is the first work-item in order to support k8s
Network-policy (work-item-list described in the blueprint).

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies
Change-Id: I0c1b85a8a363ab42685c9922b08811f8c99bce94

commit_message:
Add new schema for Nova microversion 2.63

This microversion adds the trusted_image_certificates parameter to the
server rebuild, server create, server update, and servers details
responses.

Change-Id: I48f62d36a871a95601ebf277a2f39a41a873daa8
Implements blueprint: nova-validate-certificates

commit_message:
Added scenario: MTU manipulation

This newly added test is creating two networks
with custom MTU values using the 'available_type_drivers'
and lets the user configure 'max_mtu', to enable
testing new scenarios like Jumbo Frames.
After creating the networks two instances are
spawned and trying to ping each other using different
values of MTU and with/without 'DO NOT FRAGMENT' flag.

Change-Id: Ica6ae26a8469bbfddfba30c9e193d40ca1cac67f

commit_message:
Refactor libvirt get_memory_used_mb()

Split _sum_domain_memory_mb and _get_avail_memory_kb to separate
functions. Simplifies xen codepath in get_memory_used_mb, and eases
integration for file-backed-memory

Change-Id: Ifaa866b88a04c14fbb45bc9d8cd11e847c6dd671
Implements: blueprint libvirt-file-backed-memory

Fixed a bug that occasionally causes the tempest tests to fail

test_compare_cli_vs_api_resource_list sometimes fails with an
error regarding the neutron.port state.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 10:40:02.000000000', 'message': 'Move nova cell v1 job to check pipeline

Nova cell v1 job run as experimental and it is
obvious that we miss testing the tempest changes against
this job which can leads to gate block on nova side.
One example is https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1776684

nova cell v1 is deprecated but not yet removed and this job
run on nova check and gate pipeline.

This commit moves the cell v1 job from experimental pipeline
to check pipeline on tempest side so that we can monitor it.

Once nova wil drop cell v1, Tempest can drop this job.

Change-Id: Ic01e867d590810f620b141a554a596ddd5e73fed
'}]
commit_message:
Move nova cell v1 job to check pipeline

Nova cell v1 job run as experimental and it is
obvious that we miss testing the tempest changes against
this job which can leads to gate block on nova side.
One example is https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1776684

nova cell v1 is deprecated but not yet removed and this job
run on nova check and gate pipeline.

This commit moves the cell v1 job from experimental pipeline
to check pipeline on tempest side so that we can monitor it.

Once nova wil drop cell v1, Tempest can drop this job.

Change-Id: Ic01e867d590810f620b141a554a596ddd5e73fed

[{'created': '2018-03-29 03:02:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image_id KeyError in test_create_backup

image_id is added to the result of create_backup, but it's
added in the header, it's added in body instead, so we can't
get image_id from resp.response, otherwise it will raise
"KeyError: 'image_id'". This is to fix it.

Ref: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-server-back-up-createbackup-action

Implements blueprint: clear-deprecated-api

Change-Id: If924bc417c24e5bcc18577d20023f277653d7dd3
'}, {'created': '2018-03-29 08:16:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image_id KeyError in test_create_backup

image_id is added to the result of create_backup, but it's not
added in the header, it's added in body instead, so we can't
get image_id from resp.response, otherwise it will raise
"KeyError: 'image_id'". This is to fix it.

Ref: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-server-back-up-createbackup-action

Implements blueprint: clear-deprecated-api

Change-Id: If924bc417c24e5bcc18577d20023f277653d7dd3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix image_id KeyError in test_create_backup

image_id is added to the result of create_backup, but it's not
added in the header, it's added in body instead, so we can't
get image_id from resp.response, otherwise it will raise
"KeyError: 'image_id'". This is to fix it.

Ref: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#create-server-back-up-createbackup-action

Implements blueprint: clear-deprecated-api

Change-Id: If924bc417c24e5bcc18577d20023f277653d7dd3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-05 10:04:31.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify docker vs moby containers runtime/images

For containerized undercloud as a good start, avoid using
references to Docker if only not limited to the docker CLI
commands.

Whenever we refer to *architecture* for containers runtime and
images (CRI & OCI), refer to Moby instead.

This creates less confusion for readers might be expecting more
features of Docker is used, like Swarm as COE, while it is not.

Eventually, this replacement should happen to all places.

Change-Id: Ia731d7a151f0a294297b0528173e36577ad0dfeb
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify docker vs moby containers runtime/images

For containerized undercloud as a good start, avoid using
references to Docker if only not limited to the docker CLI
commands.

Whenever we refer to *architecture* for containers runtime and
images (CRI & OCI), refer to Moby instead.

This creates less confusion for readers might be expecting more
features of Docker is used, like Swarm as COE, while it is not.

Eventually, this replacement should happen to all places.

Change-Id: Ia731d7a151f0a294297b0528173e36577ad0dfeb

maintained project to which all Openstack projects
should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

commit_message:
More retrieval options for ODL from Nexus

Currently it only tries to retrieve the version from snaphsots, but this
is only for current supported versions. Older versions require to
retrieve them from releases.

This patch triest to retrieve it from snapshots and then, if it fails,
it tries from releases.

Change-Id: I24bd16c8a8240ba5abe0e4612380b7cc22d044f1

commit_message:
neutron-taas-tcpdump: A small utility to exec tcpdump using taas

For example, the following dumps the traffic on the port specified
by the uuid:

    % cat taas-tcpdump.ini
    [DEFAULT]
    interface_driver = midonet
    ovs_use_veth = False
    debug = False
    verbose = True
    % neutron-taas-tcpdump --config-file taas-tcpdump.ini --port <uuid>

Change-Id: Iad4daaceff9dfe5005b054e12cdd1490f66d2ca2

I can reproduce the issue if I delete the path specified in CONF.instances_path . It seems that the test does not create that path but assumes that it is there. During the test CONF.instances_path is defaulted to '<test_dir>/instances' which does not exist by default."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-06-11 11:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Code-Review-1

If I make the CONF.instances_path unreadable and unwriteable for the functional tests then another tests start failing [1] with a different stack trace [1] pointing to the nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py", line 374, in resolve_driver_format . In that code path there is an ensure_tree call [2]that (I assume) creates the necessary directories recursively.

So my current working assumption is that if any of the tests from [1] runs before your new test then your test will pass, but if none of them runs before your test then your test fails. 

I suggest to create the necessary directorystructure somehow in your test fixture.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/723182/
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/3693caa54132ef3ec278d846dc50943a8d52509b/nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py#L371'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-11 13:17:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

> I suggest to create the necessary directorystructure somehow in your test fixture.

Or if we can mock something relatively easily, that would be preferred, since for what we're testing here, we don't actually care about any aspect of creating the instance."}, {'account_id': 20182, 'date': '2018-06-12 13:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-06-12 13:10:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-11 14:51:24.000000000', 'message': "WIP: libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, she must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f
"}, {'created': '2018-04-11 15:18:12.000000000', 'message': "WIP: libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, she must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f
"}, {'created': '2018-04-20 06:38:38.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, she must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because

commit_message:
libvirt: Don't report DISK_GB if sharing

For libvirt, if the operator wishes to use shared storage, they must
manually configure the sharing resource provider in placement and
associate it via aggregate with the compute node.  However, the libvirt
driver was still reporting the (same) DISK_GB inventory in the compute
node provider.

With this patch, we check the provider tree to see if a sharing provider
of DISK_GB is present.  If so, we don't report that inventory - because
it's already accounted for by the sharing provider.

Co-Authored-By: Bhagyashri Shewale <bhagyashri.shewale@nttdata.com>
Closes-Bug: #1771728
Change-Id: Iea283322124cb35fc0bc6d25f35548621e8c8c2f

commit_message:
Add split-stack environment support.

Upgrading split-stack(pre-provisioned) environments requires some
extra steps/options to be added/applied.

Change-Id: Ie84182c2273ba5d9fa7e66235ea70a73bf92bf31

commit_message:
Move L3 agent checks inside overcloud upgrade script.

Currently L3 agent checks are called from ansible tasks,
 though those scripts already exist at uc.
Current change calls those scripts from within `upgrade` script,
 which makes it easier for local reproducing.

Change-Id: Ib3a781f570155a2139b6e0cf3debfc97363c6a08

commit_message:
Fix undefined update_containers variable

When checking for update_containers var we need to check if it's
defined at all. Also all booleans should be with |bool

Closes-Bug: #1777261
Change-Id: Ied1ea6f6f0656b182a6b29fd1b69fc5596ac5f28
