- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/567678/4/ : SUCCESS in 3h 38m 41s'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-05-16 10:09:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Thank you for splitting the objects into their own files.

However, I still can see no good explanations or reasons to have User and Project objects (especially ones that are OVO), see more detailed comments within.

It's not clear what the User and Project objects are doing that is much more than the existing objects provided by sqlalchemy via api_modes.py

Let's not just add stuff because we think we might want it later.

I agree that we want a Consumer objects, and I agree that we want to always ahve consumer records but don't agree with the consistency (non-)argument being used for justifying the creation of Project and User objects."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-05-16 12:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Thank you for splitting the objects into their own files.
 > 
 > However, I still can see no good explanations or reasons to have
 > User and Project objects (especially ones that are OVO), see more
 > detailed comments within.
 >
 > It's not clear what the User and Project objects are doing that is
 > much more than the existing objects provided by sqlalchemy via
 > api_modes.py
 > 
 > Let's not just add stuff because we think we might want it later.

We added Last-Modified-On because we "might want it later", no?

 > I agree that we want a Consumer objects, and I agree that we want
 > to always ahve consumer records but don't agree with the
 > consistency (non-)argument being used for justifying the creation
 > of Project and User objects.

I feel like you are being deliberately obtuse because you don't like the concept of the Placement API understanding what a user and project are, because those things are critical concepts in other parts of OpenStack -- i.e. Nova and Keystone.

Placement was not built for your fridge. As much as that concept is cute and makes it seem like the service is stand-alone and useful outside of OpenStack, it isn't. Placement isn't the next Gnocchi.

I'm thinking ahead to what will need to happen in Placement for the service to satisfy the needs of many of other OpenStack infrastructure services, including Cinder, Neutron, and Ironic.

In the future, Placement should be used for satisfying quota usage calculations. If Placement doesn't understand what a project or user is -- including potentially the hierarchical nature of projects -- then there isn't a way that Placement can be used for answering those types of queries.

So, yes, I absolutely see a need for the placement service to eventually have (probably read-only, but who knows) API endpoints for users and projects, and I'd like to see these concepts treated just like all the other concepts that placement is intended to understand.

You can call it a consistency (non-)argument all you like.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-05-16 12:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> 
 > We added Last-Modified-On because we "might want it later", no?

No, we added it because it violates HTTP to not include that and because we had bugs with caching through proxies.

 > I feel like you are being deliberately obtuse because you don't
 > like the concept of the Placement API understanding what a user and
 > project are, because those things are critical concepts in other
 > parts of OpenStack -- i.e. Nova and Keystone.

No, I'm simply asking you to provide a description of the future that you're planning here, and to consider if perhaps we should wait for these things until later when we are actually using them.

I do not dispute that placement needs to record project and user identifiers. I do, however, dispute that placement needs to do anything more with those concepts than record them and as of yet you haven't stated what you want them to do. So I don't think it is wrong of me, as a reviewer to ask, and if I don't get a satisfactory answer to say "maybe we should wait".

That's what review is for.

 > Placement was not built for your fridge. As much as that concept is
 > cute and makes it seem like the service is stand-alone and useful
 > outside of OpenStack, it isn't. Placement isn't the next Gnocchi.

I'm really getting sick of you making snarky jokes about this fridge stuff as well as placement leaving openstack. I think it demonstrates a misunderstanding of the effort I'm making to try to make placement understandable to a wider audience. I didn't make the fridge thing to say "let's use placement outside of OpenStack". I made it to show that placement can, with a bit of effort, be nicely decoupled from things, following the presumption that such decoupling is a good thing. I mean why would we bother to make it an HTTP API if we didn't care about decoupling?

Snarking about Gnocchi is really taking me on bad faith here, and is very disappointing and makes me want to flip a table and generally tell you to fuck off, but I'm going to refrain because I want to take you on good faith.

We're both trying to make placement a good piece of software. One of my goals is to keep it light, simple, focused. That's good design. So each time we add an OVO I'm going to say "do we really need this?"

That's fair and correct, right? If not, I clearly missed a memo somewhere and I'm not sure I should bother to carry on reviewing.

 > I'm thinking ahead to what will need to happen in Placement for the
 > service to satisfy the needs of many of other OpenStack
 > infrastructure services, including Cinder, Neutron, and Ironic.
 > 
 > In the future, Placement should be used for satisfying quota usage
 > calculations. If Placement doesn't understand what a project or
 > user is -- including potentially the hierarchical nature of
 > projects -- then there isn't a way that Placement can be used for
 > answering those types of queries.

Again, I'm not asking that placement not understand what a project or user is. I'm asking: why does placement need to understand anything more than that just the identifiers for such thing (and isntead potentially use other services which are more "about" those service)? I'm _asking_. And until there's an answer I will keep asking.

 > So, yes, I absolutely see a need for the placement service to
 > eventually have (probably read-only, but who knows) API endpoints
 > for users and projects, and I'd like to see these concepts treated
 > just like all the other concepts that placement is intended to
 > understand.

This paragraph begins to answer it, but doesn't go all the way. What will those endpoints do? When someone queries /users or /projects in Placement what are they querying for? What use cases are being supported by being able to query those things? Why is querying placement for these things better than querying something else?

These are legit questions to be asking.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-05-16 13:31:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> >
 > > We added Last-Modified-On because we "might want it later", no?
 > 
 > No, we added it because it violates HTTP to not include that and
 > because we had bugs with caching through proxies.
 > 
 > > I feel like you are being deliberately obtuse because you don't
 > > like the concept of the Placement API understanding what a user
 > and
 > > project are, because those things are critical concepts in other
 > > parts of OpenStack -- i.e. Nova and Keystone.
 > 
 > No, I'm simply asking you to provide a description of the future
 > that you're planning here, and to consider if perhaps we should
 > wait for these things until later when we are actually using them.

I don't see the point in waiting for that.

 > > Placement was not built for your fridge. As much as that concept
 > is
 > > cute and makes it seem like the service is stand-alone and useful
 > > outside of OpenStack, it isn't. Placement isn't the next Gnocchi.
 > 
 > I'm really getting sick of you making snarky jokes about this
 > fridge stuff as well as placement leaving openstack. I think it
 > demonstrates a misunderstanding of the effort I'm making to try to
 > make placement understandable to a wider audience. I didn't make
 > the fridge thing to say "let's use placement outside of OpenStack".
 > I made it to show that placement can, with a bit of effort, be
 > nicely decoupled from things, following the presumption that such
 > decoupling is a good thing. I mean why would we bother to make it
 > an HTTP API if we didn't care about decoupling?
 > 
 > Snarking about Gnocchi is really taking me on bad faith here, and
 > is very disappointing and makes me want to flip a table and
 > generally tell you to fuck off, but I'm going to refrain because I
 > want to take you on good faith.

I wasn't snarking at all. I was being direct. And you can tell me to fuck off, which is exactly what you just did.

You have repeatedly pointed out on IRC that requiring a project and user for allocations doesn't sit well with you because you want placement to exist outside of the bounds of Nova (and presumably OpenStack). Your fridge is the very thing *you* keep bringing up as an example of something that should be able to use placement and not "have to care about projects and users".

 > We're both trying to make placement a good piece of software. One
 > of my goals is to keep it light, simple, focused. That's good
 > design. So each time we add an OVO I'm going to say "do we really
 > need this?"

You hate OVO. I get it. But it's what Placement uses for its object modeling for now. If you want to, go ahead and remove all use of OVO, but you are using your distaste of that library as a crutch to say we shouldn't model projects and users with objects.

 > > I'm thinking ahead to what will need to happen in Placement for
 > the
 > > service to satisfy the needs of many of other OpenStack
 > > infrastructure services, including Cinder, Neutron, and Ironic.
 > >
 > > In the future, Placement should be used for satisfying quota
 > usage
 > > calculations. If Placement doesn't understand what a project or
 > > user is -- including potentially the hierarchical nature of
 > > projects -- then there isn't a way that Placement can be used for
 > > answering those types of queries.
 > 
 > Again, I'm not asking that placement not understand what a project
 > or user is. I'm asking: why does placement need to understand
 > anything more than that just the identifiers for such thing (and
 > isntead potentially use other services which are more "about" those
 > service)? I'm _asking_. And until there's an answer I will keep
 > asking.
 > 
 > > So, yes, I absolutely see a need for the placement service to
 > > eventually have (probably read-only, but who knows) API endpoints
 > > for users and projects, and I'd like to see these concepts
 > treated
 > > just like all the other concepts that placement is intended to
 > > understand.
 > 
 > This paragraph begins to answer it, but doesn't go all the way.
 > What will those endpoints do? When someone queries /users or
 > /projects in Placement what are they querying for? What use cases
 > are being supported by being able to query those things? Why is
 > querying placement for these things better than querying something
 > else?
 > 
 > These are legit questions to be asking.

You're right, they are absolutely legit questions to be asking.

I don't know how else to answer those questions to satisfy you. I want to be consistent in how we handle and model objects in the system. I feel that is reason enough, but I've tried to outline to you why project and user information -- in particular the knowledge of the hierarchy of projects is needed to answer quota usage queries.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-05-16 14:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I don't see the point in waiting for that.

The point is we seem to have a lot on the plate and a lot of stuff undone and could punt on some stuff that we could do later.

 > I wasn't snarking at all. I was being direct. And you can tell me
 > to fuck off, which is exactly what you just did.

It certainly seemed like snarking to me. Bring in bullshit about gnocchi that has both nothing to do with this change as well as nothing to do with me and for which we already have history of me telling you to leave me alone about. Being grumpy about the placecat stuff (which is just a demo suite) when it too has nothing to do with this. It's clear you've got beef and it is getting in the way of you being sanguine about this stuff. From my standpoint you have some kind of issue with what I've been up to lately, with me in general, or specifically with me questioning you. You should figure that out before you get back to me. It is exceptionally clear to me that you don't like me, in particular, disagreeing with you. Fix that. Is that direct enough?

 > You have repeatedly pointed out on IRC that requiring a project and
 > user for allocations doesn't sit well with you because you want
 > placement to exist outside of the bounds of Nova (and presumably
 > OpenStack). Your fridge is the very thing *you* keep bringing up as
 > an example of something that should be able to use placement and
 > not "have to care about projects and users".

Again, you are incorrectly recalling my position and apparently not correctly reading what I've written even today. I have said many times that I understand why we need project and user information with allocations and that I'm happy to see them exist. What I said, using the fridge as a metaphoric example, is that I'd like to preserve the ability to use the old microversion where carrying a project and user in the request package is not required for, indeed, systems that do not need or want to care about projects and users. That the fridge example somehow didn't come across as a metaphor for "other stuff we haven't thought of yet" is probably my fault because I'm too embedded in the idea of HTTP APIs being expressly about enabling "stuff we haven't thought of yet". My apologies, I'll try to be more clear in the future.

How those desires equate to not wanting allocations to have project and user information at all is beyond me and I fear the result of a lens of interpretation distorted by...well, I'm not really sure what.

The fridge is a tool to help people understand what is possible with placement. As far as I can tell the fact that I'm exploring multiple ways of using placement bothers you for some reason. I'm sorry about that. I wish it didn't because I have learned a lot about placement, nova, openstack and many other things as a result of those experiments and I hope to be able to pass that learning on to other people. I perceive that to be a big part of what I'm supposed to do as a "maintainer".

 > You hate OVO. I get it. But it's what Placement uses for its object
 > modeling for now. If you want to, go ahead and remove all use of
 > OVO, but you are using your distaste of that library as a crutch to
 > say we shouldn't model projects and users with objects.

I do dislike OVO, but I am accepting of them in our current context. They are convenient as we currently use them. I'm not questioning that we have OVO Project and OVO User. I'm questioning that we have Project and User objects of any kind, because I haven't read anything (until your final paragraph quoted below) about why we want them.

 > > This paragraph begins to answer it, but doesn't go all the way.
 > > What will those endpoints do? When someone queries /users or
 > > /projects in Placement what are they querying for? What use cases
 > > are being supported by being able to query those things? Why is
 > > querying placement for these things better than querying
 > something
 > > else?
 > >
 > > These are legit questions to be asking.
 > 
 > You're right, they are absolutely legit questions to be asking.
 > 
 > I don't know how else to answer those questions to satisfy you. I
 > want to be consistent in how we handle and model objects in the
 > system. I feel that is reason enough, but I've tried to outline to
 > you why project and user information -- in particular the knowledge
 > of the hierarchy of projects is needed to answer quota usage
 > queries.
 
You could start by answering those questions in the quoted paragraphs above:

* What will those endpoints do?
* When someone queries /users or /projects in Placement what are they querying for?
* Why is querying placement for these things better than querying something else?

There's some incremental progress in your response. You say you think it is important for modelling project hierarchy for quota usage queries. Great. Where is that in this commit that I've missed? If it's not there, can you add it? Or if it is there but is non-obvious can you make it more explicit, especially in the commit message?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-05-18 15:51:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-10 19:23:08.000000000', 'message': "placement: always create consumer records

Adds objects for Consumer, Project, and User data models, in their own
files. They do not contain logic that comes from the API microversions
and are meant to be plain-old-data objects that represent the current
schema in the database. Project, user and consumer information all are
stored in separate tables in the DB and represent actual things in the
placement data modeling. Giving them actual objects makes that
consistent with the other objects in the data model, including resource
providers, allocations, inventories, resource classes and traits.

The patch modifies the allocation handler to always ensure that a
consumer record exists for the supplied consumer UUID and an associated
projects and users table record exists for that consumer. If an
allocation is created using API microversion <1.8, which doesn't supply
the project or user for the consumer, we use the value of two new CONF
options that indicate the project and user ID for incomplete consumer
records.

Includes an online data migration for the nova-manage
online_data_migrations command that creates consumer records for
incomplete consumers.

Change-Id: Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a

allocation is created using API microversion <1.8, which doesn't supply
the project or user for the consumer, we use the value of two new CONF
options that indicate the project and user ID for incomplete consumer
records.

Includes an online data migration for the nova-manage
online_data_migrations command that creates consumer records for
incomplete consumers.

Change-Id: Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a

commit_message:
placement: always create consumer records

Adds objects for Consumer, Project, and User data models, in their own
files. They do not contain logic that comes from the API microversions
and are meant to be plain-old-data objects that represent the current
schema in the database. Project, user and consumer information all are
stored in separate tables in the DB and represent actual things in the
placement data modeling. Giving them actual objects makes that
consistent with the other objects in the data model, including resource
providers, allocations, inventories, resource classes and traits.

The patch modifies the allocation handler to always ensure that a
consumer record exists for the supplied consumer UUID and an associated
projects and users table record exists for that consumer. If an
allocation is created using API microversion <1.8, which doesn't supply
the project or user for the consumer, we use the value of two new CONF
options that indicate the project and user ID for incomplete consumer
records.

Includes an online data migration for the nova-manage
online_data_migrations command that creates consumer records for
incomplete consumers.

Change-Id: Id609789ef6b4a4c745550cde80dd49cabe03869a

[{'created': '2018-06-11 02:40:28.000000000', 'message': '[Unity] Add support of removing empty host

Add an option in Unity Cinder driver to customize the removing
of empty host. The option is named `remove_empty_host`. Its
default value is False. When it is set to True, the host will
be removed from Unity after the last LUN is detached from it.

Change-Id: I2d9fad2c977a61f5b26a6449a8e509911eff28e0
Closes-bug: #1768711
(cherry picked from commit f9a9aa5a25688cac86e5dc060a20374e4a29bbef)
(cherry picked from commit 24bd0c4b645dbcb99977e6a3e16c51979455b1eb)
'}]
commit_message:
[Unity] Add support of removing empty host

Add an option in Unity Cinder driver to customize the removing
of empty host. The option is named `remove_empty_host`. Its
default value is False. When it is set to True, the host will
be removed from Unity after the last LUN is detached from it.

Change-Id: I2d9fad2c977a61f5b26a6449a8e509911eff28e0
Closes-bug: #1768711
(cherry picked from commit f9a9aa5a25688cac86e5dc060a20374e4a29bbef)
(cherry picked from commit 24bd0c4b645dbcb99977e6a3e16c51979455b1eb)

func tests: Rename storage_url to storage_path

... so we can use storage_url for actual, complete URLs.
Also, expose storage_scheme for easier comparisons.

commit_message:
Fix docker images validation script

Set overcloud_validate_ap_services_list var and filter the pcmklatest
image out of the images used for a/p services check.

Closes-bug: 1776262

Change-Id: I28158373c7d448e909f5a090c5bf1be5450a24e0
(cherry picked from commit 46ffad4add0f954c8087cb2b6c4716eebed10afd)

commit_message:
Remove share_backend_name from Dell-EMC manila backends

This parameter has a default value from puppet-manila
ex: [1], and doesn't need to be specified here.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/puppet-manila/tree/manifests/backend/dellemc_unity.pp

Change-Id: I7fa8ffd9af459f138bc182fd6bd307471c87f75d
Closes-Bug: #1771656
(cherry picked from commit 3d0451285166193337ad3ece6031e1564a82d4b0)

[{'created': '2017-08-28 18:50:02.000000000', 'message': "Enable swift3 by default

The swift3 package has always been available in TripleO
deployments, but so far users have had to enable it
manually. Let's enable it by default

commit_message:
Enable s3api by default

Swift3 has been imported into swift's code base
as s3api middleware. Let's enable it by default
in TripleO.

Related-Change-Id: I9c61d48e673d513cb4c5cf0c9f8b7d1b894729eb
Related-Change-Id: I7f085b0c05f2b8c50e7f94ca1c7f4670660da688
Change-Id: Ib6ca60c8e6b7c123747e8e8b9de1d55df8311031
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

Add NFS backend for cinder-backup service

Add a Cinder backup profile that uses NFS for the backend.

Change-Id: Ic0adb294aa2e60243f8adaf167bdd75e42c8e20e

commit_message:
Rename test_except.py -> test_catch_errors.py

Every other middleware has files swift/common/middleware/<mw>.py and
test/unit/common/middleware/test_<mw>.py, while catch_errors has
test_except.py, which makes its tests harder to find. Let's follow the
same naming pattern.

Change-Id: I534ff57ac2fe8e12a3f84d821da04d679f1ced3a

commit_message:
Set tuned profile for compute roles

Computes should have virtual-host tuned profile set per default in
roles definition. HCI compute as recommended before keep
throughput-performance.

Fixes bug 1667524

Change-Id: I26426e1dd0a2e81ad7549c11fb984ef5470d0561

subject: Fix logrotate_crond issues
messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-06-14 18:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-06-15 07:33:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2018-06-15 07:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 16282, 'date': '2018-06-15 12:23:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-06-15 16:59:37.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned\n\nwe have gate problems again, please do not restore or recheck, I'll take care of this one when gate is back stable."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-06-15 19:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-14 18:49:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logrotate_crond issues

So currently the logrotate_crond container has a few issues issues:
A) In the postrotate it matches pids multiple times and sends SIGHUPs multiple time to processes:
    ======== /var/log/messages =====
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd
...

Adding sort -u in the pipeline of the postrotate script takes care of
that.

B) The logrotate_crond container should not rotate logs for services
running on the host outside of containers (i.e. rsyslog has its own
/etc/logrotate.d/rsyslog rules). Doing so violates the principle of
least surprise.

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' takes care of this as we won't
match any non containerized processes

C) The find command matches older files to be deleted but the SIGHUP is
never sent so we actually can end up in a situation where we remove a
file but the new one never gets created because the service does not get
a SIGHUP signal:

ls -la /var/log/containers/httpd/*/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 52046652 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 0 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/error_log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 50755274 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 4138 May 25 11:58 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:13 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/error_log

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' fixes this case as well because
now we correctly match the processes that have a deleted file that is
open and we send a proper SIGHUP to them.

Tested by doing the following:
1) Logging rotation of containerized services (B, C)
1.1) Stopped the keystone container
1.2) Made the /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log file 21M large
1.3) Started the keystone container and observed that it was logging
     correctly to /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log
1.4) Inside the logrotate_crond container we ran the following:
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
1.5) We observed correct log rotation and keystone was notified via
SIGHUP and started logging correctly:
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425 21628706 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log.1
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425      999 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log

2) No SIGHUP to host processes (A)
2.1) stopped rsyslog on the host and made one of its log files > 10M:
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 28M Jun 13 08:59 /var/log/messages
2.2) restart rsyslog
2.3) Ran the logrotation inside the container
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533
(cherry picked from commit 77d93f32873e740b0f04f323465ad14c044c896b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix logrotate_crond issues

So currently the logrotate_crond container has a few issues issues:
A) In the postrotate it matches pids multiple times and sends SIGHUPs multiple time to processes:
    ======== /var/log/messages =====
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd" swVersion="8.24.0" x-pid="1575" x-info="http://www.rsyslog.com"] rsyslogd was HUPed
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 logrotate-crond: kill -HUP 1575
    Jun 3 09:01:15 overcloud-controller-0 rsyslogd: [origin software="rsyslogd
...

Adding sort -u in the pipeline of the postrotate script takes care of
that.

B) The logrotate_crond container should not rotate logs for services
running on the host outside of containers (i.e. rsyslog has its own
/etc/logrotate.d/rsyslog rules). Doing so violates the principle of
least surprise.

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' takes care of this as we won't
match any non containerized processes

C) The find command matches older files to be deleted but the SIGHUP is
never sent so we actually can end up in a situation where we remove a
file but the new one never gets created because the service does not get
a SIGHUP signal:

ls -la /var/log/containers/httpd/*/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 52046652 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 0 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/error_log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 50755274 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 4138 May 25 11:58 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:13 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/error_log

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' fixes this case as well because
now we correctly match the processes that have a deleted file that is
open and we send a proper SIGHUP to them.

Tested by doing the following:
1) Logging rotation of containerized services (B, C)
1.1) Stopped the keystone container
1.2) Made the /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log file 21M large
1.3) Started the keystone container and observed that it was logging
     correctly to /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log
1.4) Inside the logrotate_crond container we ran the following:
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
1.5) We observed correct log rotation and keystone was notified via
SIGHUP and started logging correctly:
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425 21628706 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log.1
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425      999 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log

2) No SIGHUP to host processes (A)
2.1) stopped rsyslog on the host and made one of its log files > 10M:
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 28M Jun 13 08:59 /var/log/messages
2.2) restart rsyslog
2.3) Ran the logrotation inside the container
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533
(cherry picked from commit 77d93f32873e740b0f04f323465ad14c044c896b)

SIGHUP and started logging correctly:

2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

NB: Cherry-pick to pike omitted the part around finding files older
    than X days as that feature did not exist

file but the new one never gets created because the service does not get
a SIGHUP signal:

ls -la /var/log/containers/httpd/*/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 52046652 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 0 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/aodh_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:14 /var/log/containers/httpd/aodh-api/error_log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 50755274 May 29 14:10 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_access.log.1
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 4138 May 25 11:58 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/cinder_wsgi_error.log
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 5894 May 24 19:13 /var/log/containers/httpd/cinder-api/error_log

Using 'lsof ..+D /var/log/containers' fixes this case as well because
now we correctly match the processes that have a deleted file that is
open and we send a proper SIGHUP to them.

Tested by doing the following:
1) Logging rotation of containerized services (B, C)
1.1) Stopped the keystone container
1.2) Made the /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log file 21M large
1.3) Started the keystone container and observed that it was logging
     correctly to /var/log/container/keystone/keystone.log
1.4) Inside the logrotate_crond container we ran the following:
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
1.5) We observed correct log rotation and keystone was notified via
SIGHUP and started logging correctly:
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425 21628706 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log.1
-rw-r--r--.  1 42425 42425      999 Jun 13 08:43 keystone.log

2) No SIGHUP to host processes (A)
2.1) stopped rsyslog on the host and made one of its log files > 10M:
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 28M Jun 13 08:59 /var/log/messages
2.2) restart rsyslog
2.3) Ran the logrotation inside the container
/usr/sbin/logrotate -s /var/lib/logrotate/logrotate-crond.status /etc/logrotate-crond.conf
2.4) Observed that no SIGHUP was sent to rsyslog on the host

Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>

NB: Cherry-pick to pike omitted the part around finding files older
    than X days as that feature did not exist

Change-Id: I5029a4b9c76268455812696290aaf82f1a0c2c23
Closes-Bug: #1776533
(cherry picked from commit 77d93f32873e740b0f04f323465ad14c044c896b)

commit_message:
Document the internal online_migrations function behaviors

This adds a comment to the online_migrations definition, explaining the
calling and return conventions of those functions so that future
developers can return the proper thing for the CLI's UX.

Change-Id: If8dafc145c19830f7099c1c5f66148930ee7f59c

commit_message:
Add supplementary info for simple_cell_setup cmd

Mention that if no transport_url is provided then the one
in the configuration file will be used for command
``nova-manage cell_v2 simple_cell_setup [--transport-url <transport_url>]``,
just like that for other cell_v2 commands.

Change-Id: Ifededa59f7ffe5887e67e29b93f70fa70dfaef33

[{'created': '2018-04-27 02:59:38.000000000', 'message': "ifcfg: don't restart ovs if --no-activate is specified

When --no-activate is specified, there is a chance that
openvswitch service will still be restarted if dpdk port
configuration file is changed. This adds a condition to
check activate and restart openvswitch only if activate
is true.

Change-Id: Ia5a6d04eb26cc3a6e10caacb8256d6e2d183239e

"}]
commit_message:
ifcfg: don't restart ovs if --no-activate is specified

When --no-activate is specified, there is a chance that
openvswitch service will still be restarted if dpdk port
configuration file is changed. This adds a condition to
check activate and restart openvswitch only if activate
is true.

Change-Id: Ia5a6d04eb26cc3a6e10caacb8256d6e2d183239e
Closes-Bug: #1751955
(cherry picked from commit 9e3436262d14fd90c19c271ae66474ea5eef4ec1)

commit_message:
Break out setup and always tag facts

This change breaks out the basic install and setup playbooks into
different playbooks. This is done to ensure an operator can easily rerun
any part of the playbook as they upgrade, change, or modify a setup over
the lifetime of the deployment.

Change-Id: I66c53fcb21880c950ea3fee202e7d2224dfdff3a
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add GeoIP capabilities into logstash

The geoip capabilities are built into logstash and can help a deployer
better understand the workloads they're running within their
environments. This change adds geoip capabilities in line with the
recommended practice from elastic.

Link: https://www.elastic.co/blog/geoip-in-the-elastic-stack

Change-Id: I109879bd9aeeaa0312eb3303e2e7566181ecff91
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Breakup site into more consumable meta playbooks

The site playbook was a running list of all playbooks throughout the
stack. This change breaks up site so that deployers can update different
components of the stack without having to call the individual playbooks.

Change-Id: I6a2c4959806928a4f0dd143a2ebac9c0505fb1ca
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fix Port OVO filtering based on security groups

Filtering of port OVO based on ids of security groups which
are used by ports is now available.

Closes-Bug: 1744447

Change-Id: Ie5a3effe668db119d40728be5357f0851bdcebbe
(cherry picked from commit e7c0ec17df83da3c7ba3f453ad8935320c471eb8)

I tested it and it is working. It is nice that you added the release note, but please add the documentation into the kuryr-kubernetes doc folder (probably inside installation one). Moreover, related to the documentation at the google doc, note that I added to devstack the option to specify the list of handlers to enable (instead of having to enable them after stacking), so you could simply add the next before stacking:

commit_message:
OCP-Router: OCP-Route and Ingress LBaaS handlers

This is the third patch of the Ingress Controller capability.

This patch implements OCP-Route and Ingress LBaaS handlers.
Those handlers should retrieve the L7 LB details from the
Ingress controller and update L7 policy/rules and pool/members
upon changes in OCP-route and k8S-endpoint resources.

Please follow the instructions below to verify
OCP-Router functionality:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1c3mfBToBbWlwFcw3S8fr7pQZb5_YZqFYdlG1HqaQPkQ/edit?usp=sharing

Implements: blueprint openshift-router-support

Change-Id: Ibfb6cda6dde9613ad31859d38235be031ade0639

Hi Irena,

I wonder how all the gates are green ?'}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-02-12 12:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Yossi, not sure what currently checked with OpenShift gates. As long as there is no Igress/Route definition do you still expect it to fail?'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-13 11:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Irena,

(3 comments)

Great work Yossi! It is still pretty big patch set so I would like to take another look as well as to try it out myself. I found a few nits. Also, I'm not sure the ingress_ctl.py should be on kuryr_kubernetes/ or inside kuryr_kubernetes/controllers or somewhere else. What was the reason of having it on the base directory?"}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-15 17:09:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-15 21:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-15 21:48:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

Luis,

1. Please find my comments inline

2. As per the ingress_ctl.py location, the ingress controller is an independent/infra entity, IMHO it shouldn't be part of the kuryr controller (that's watches K8S resources and perform the consequent actions).
I think that base directory is good/reasonable location for the ingress_ctl.py file , any other ideas  ?"}, {'account_id': 6598, 'date': '2018-02-16 17:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-18 12:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-02-22 10:13:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

thanks Yossi, I have a few comments (mostly nits)

Regarding the location of the ingressctl, I still think it should be inside the controller folder, as:
- It is triggered by controller/service.py
- It will run in the kuryr-controller pod

Perhaps it does not need to be inside controller/drivers or controller/handlers, but a new folder (similarly to the healthcheck manager), for example controller/ingress/ingress_ctl.py. What do you think about this option?'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-26 00:09:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-02-26 00:18:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

I am not quite convinced of creating the router ourselves. Isn't it better to let deployment handle that for us? In any case, it's probably better to consider automatic creation in a separate patch"}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-02 19:48:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> I am not quite convinced of creating the router ourselves. Isn't it
 > better to let deployment handle that for us? In any case, it's
 > probably better to consider automatic creation in a separate patch
Yes, it makes sense that in the majority of cases the user will set ingress=Enable at deployment phase, and router should be created by deployment.
But I think we should also (maybe not in the first phase) support enable Kuryr ingress controller post-install (KuryrCtl plugin?), and we better re-use the router deployment code.

In the bottom line, I'm fine with enable/disable ingress functionality only at deployment at this phase(and router won't be created by Us).
I'll update the code with this approach."}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2018-03-02 23:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I agree. Thanks Yossi'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-04 21:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-03-09 08:42:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

- Add documentation to doc/source/installation about how to use/test this

For the tests request, feel free to wait until others review the patch set in case other changes are needed'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-13 14:16:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-13 14:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

This patch composed from two parts :
A. Readiness for new PaaS
B. Common part of Ingress Controller

Readiness for new PaaS - extend kuryr-kubernetes to support other platforms
                         (e.g: openshift)  that extend kubernetes.
Common part of Ingress Controller - that includes the L7 router and L7
                                router driver.

Partially Implements: blueprint openshift-router-support

'}, {'created': '2018-03-29 13:56:35.000000000', 'message': "OCP-Router: Ingress controller support

In order for the K8S Ingress and OpenShift Route resources to work,
the cluster must have an Ingress Controller running.
An Ingress Controller watches the apiserver's K8S Ingress and
OpenShift Route endpoints for updates. Its job is to satisfy
requests for both Ingresses and OpenShift Routes.

This patch implements the following components of the Ingress Controller:
1. L7 Router
2. L7 Router driver

Partially Implements: blueprint openshift-router-sup

Change-Id: Id55169f6c9c1c607b2aa54c92711dfbd04a9e39d

commit_message:
OCP-Router: Ingress controller support

This is the second patch of the Ingress Controller capability.

In order for the K8S Ingress and OpenShift Route resources to work,
the cluster must have an Ingress Controller running.

This patch extends LBaaS driver to support L7 load balancing and
verifies, retrieves and stores the L7 router LB (pre-created by admin or
Devstack) details.
The OCP-route and K8S-endpoint handlers (implemented in next patch) will
query the ingress controller for the L7 router details.

Partially Implements: blueprint openshift-router-support

Change-Id: Id55169f6c9c1c607b2aa54c92711dfbd04a9e39d

serviceable ports checking on host performs a "contains" operation of
sub-string match which checks the wrong port binding profile for host

commit_message:
Fix DVR scheduling checks wrong profile for host

When DVR scheduling in live-migration, the current implementation in DVR
serviceable ports checking on host performs a "contains" operation of
sub-string match which checks the wrong port binding profile for host
(i.e. compute-1 will also match compute-10).

Add quotes to force an exact match of the host name in the port binding
profile dictionary to address this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1776255
Change-Id: I0d2bd9b9ff0aa58a7cce1b8da2a5f21ac6b38c57
Signed-off-by: Kailun Qin <kailun.qin@intel.com>

subject: Stop using encoding='utf-8' with msgpack
messages:
[{'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-05-30 21:59:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-02 02:18:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We will need to bump up lower-constraints. I'll look to get that added as well."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 00:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 05:24:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 06:00:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 06:01:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 07:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 07:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-03 14:49:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I'm trying to understand if this is backwards compatible. It seems like it, but is msgpack data used in any places where we have to worry about deployers accessing it directly (notifications, etc.)? Does this change the resulting format of the messages so that new values might be stored differently? Does msgpack automatically deal with that?"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-06-03 17:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

As far as I can tell, this is not used in any other way (in oslo_serialization you can't change encoding=) and the raw=False forces a load utilizing utf-8.

From what I can see the bytes_as_raw/raw KWARG is intended to mirror the effective mechanism we were getting with encoding='utf-8' and it is likely no one every used anything but utf-8 here.

If someone is leveraging oslo_serialization to serialize and then deserialize elsewhere (or the inverse), we can only do "best effort", but as shown with deprecation warning, encoding= is going away and we need to move forward.

My guess is this will have a net impact of "no one even notices except less log spam", but I have to go with a bit of a gut feeling here.

From the readme on the msgpack library ( https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-python/blob/b10cf78f54a5daab866b19c32e45e207d838f52b/README.rst#deprecating-encoding-option ):

Deprecating encoding option
encoding and unicode_errors options are deprecated.

In case of packer, use UTF-8 always. Storing other than UTF-8 is not recommended.

For backward compatibility, you can use use_bin_type=False and pack bytes object into msgpack raw type.

In case of unpacker, there is new raw option. It is True by default for backward compatibility, but it is changed to False in near future. You can use raw=False instead of encoding='utf-8'.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-03 18:58:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

> As far as I can tell, this is not used in any other way (in
 > oslo_serialization you can't change encoding=) and the raw=False
 > forces a load utilizing utf-8.
 > 
 > From what I can see the bytes_as_raw/raw KWARG is intended to
 > mirror the effective mechanism we were getting with
 > encoding='utf-8' and it is likely no one every used anything but
 > utf-8 here.
 > 
 > If someone is leveraging oslo_serialization to serialize and then
 > deserialize elsewhere (or the inverse), we can only do "best
 > effort", but as shown with deprecation warning, encoding= is going
 > away and we need to move forward.

Sure. The case I'm worried about is someone using the output of oslo.serialization as input to something else. I don't know enough about how the library is actually used in other services to know when that might come up, and a search in codesearch.openstack.org doesn't expose anything obvious, so maybe that's not a case to be concerned about.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-06-15 19:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Stop using encoding='utf-8' with msgpack

msgpack is throwing a warning that the unpacker has deprecated the use
of encoding argument. Instead the unpacker uses `raw=False`, which
does an unpack with similar behavior to the old encoding='utf-8'
mechanism.

This will reduce a lot of warning spam for projects using msgpack
such as Keystone. The change to the kwarg "raw" from "bytes_as_raw"
happned between 0.5.1 and 0.5.2. Changing the lower constraint is
required to ensure the new arguments are matching the method
signature.

Change-Id: Iadbee3ec8def9512369a415fb4603dc05d0cbc56

commit_message:
Set lower bounds on all requirements and test-requirements

I just took these from the current versions at
https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/lower-constraints.txt
so we can get the the change we *actually* want, which is to black-list
a known-bad version of eventlet.

Change-Id: I9842c9975821bda5c7d8bf2fc214480c0c0a5e96

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-08 08:12:44.000000000', 'message': '[Fullstack] Wait for SG to be applied by L2 agent

In fullstack test_securitygroup there were used simple
net_helpers.assert_ping() and assert_not_ping() functions
which tries to ping IP address 3 times with some short timeout
and test fails if result of ping will not be as expected.

Unfortunately sometimes in fullstack tests it might be not enough
if test is creating new SG or SG rule or apply SG to port and
just after that checks connection because L2 agent don't have
enough time to apply all rules on "host".
This patch changes it to use block_until_ping() and
block_until_no_ping() methods from FakeMachine fixture.
It will also check if ping is possible/not possible but
will try to check it for 1 minute before fails.

Similar change is also done for methods which checks TCP
connectivity using netcat helper class. It now uses
common_utils.wait_until_true() helper function instead of
fail immediatelly.

Change-Id: I9e523d803e3c49d5d090ae5b9d36d43ce7311535
Closes-Bug: #1774006
Closes-Bug: #1767829
(cherry picked from commit 11b41d73b48d46b7725bb97d4b85158d8bc2acfb)
'}]
commit_message:
[Fullstack] Wait for SG to be applied by L2 agent

In fullstack test_securitygroup there were used simple
net_helpers.assert_ping() and assert_not_ping() functions
which tries to ping IP address 3 times with some short timeout
and test fails if result of ping will not be as expected.

Unfortunately sometimes in fullstack tests it might be not enough
if test is creating new SG or SG rule or apply SG to port and
just after that checks connection because L2 agent don't have
enough time to apply all rules on "host".
This patch changes it to use block_until_ping() and
block_until_no_ping() methods from FakeMachine fixture.
It will also check if ping is possible/not possible but
will try to check it for 1 minute before fails.

Similar change is also done for methods which checks TCP
connectivity using netcat helper class. It now uses
common_utils.wait_until_true() helper function instead of
fail immediatelly.

Change-Id: I9e523d803e3c49d5d090ae5b9d36d43ce7311535
Closes-Bug: #1774006
Closes-Bug: #1767829
(cherry picked from commit 11b41d73b48d46b7725bb97d4b85158d8bc2acfb)

subject: Only try to fetch or sync shard ranges if the remote supports sharding
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-08 19:21:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-06-08 19:23:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Seems sane to me, but I'm no expert here."}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-11 07:36:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Seems like a workable idea. It will need some tests.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-12 23:43:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-13 11:39:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(5 comments)

Makes sense. Even when the remote is not updated we do not want to replicate objects to it if the local can shard, so there is no different course of action to take given that we can infer that the remote has not been upgraded.

This is relevant but not dependent https://review.openstack.org/575084'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-13 17:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-14 12:17:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This WFM except on further reflection I think replication should be considered to have failed if shard ranges cannot be sent (see inline comment).

I tried this out by sharding a container on one node then rolling back the container server on another node to pre-sharding swift.

Without this patch I see, on the replication sender:

 Jun 14 11:01:26 localhost container-replicator: ERROR Bad response 500 from 127.0.0.1

and on the rolled-back destination:

  Jun 14 11:01:26 localhost container-server: ERROR __call__ error with REPLICATE /sdb1/692/ad37152c77abbd7e2b050d0f4628bea4 : #012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/container/server.py", line 593, in __call__#012    :data:`~swift.common.utils.ShardRange.STATES`.#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 1680, in _timing_stats#012    def transfer_rate(self, metric, elapsed_time, byte_xfer, sample_rate=None):#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/container/server.py", line 543, in REPLICATE#012    'bytes': size, 'hash': etag, 'name': name.decode('utf8'),#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/common/db_replicator.py", line 769, in dispatch#012    node['device'])#012AttributeError: 'ContainerReplicatorRpc' object has no attribute 'get_shard_ranges'
Jun 14 11:01:26 localhost container-server: STDERR: 127.0.0.1 - - [14/Jun/2018 10:01:26] "REPLICATE /sdb1/692/ad37152c77abbd7e2b050d0f4628bea4 HTTP/1.1" 500 772 0.003080
Jun 14 11:01:26 localhost container-server: ERROR __call__ error with REPLICATE /sdb1/692/ad37152c77abbd7e2b050d0f4628bea4 : #012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/container/server.py", line 593, in __call__#012    :data:`~swift.common.utils.ShardRange.STATES`.#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/common/utils.py", line 1680, in _timing_stats#012    def transfer_rate(self, metric, elapsed_time, byte_xfer, sample_rate=None):#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/container/server.py", line 543, in REPLICATE#012    'bytes': size, 'hash': etag, 'name': name.decode('utf8'),#012  File "/home/swift/swift/swift/common/db_replicator.py", line 769, in dispatch#012    node['device'])#012AttributeError: 'ContainerReplicatorRpc' object has no attribute 'merge_shard_ranges'
Jun 14 11:01:26 localhost container-server: STDERR: 127.0.0.1 - - [14/Jun/2018 10:01:26] "REPLICATE /sdb1/692/ad37152c77abbd7e2b050d0f4628bea4 HTTP/1.1" 500 774 0.009672

Upgrading the sender to this patch eliminates the error messages on both nodes.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-15 00:00:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-15 00:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-15 08:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-06-15 08:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:11:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
improve the documentation for option location information

Fix an error in the example code by setting loc to the Location enum
value instead of the LocationInfo tuple.

Add a cross-reference from the ConfigOpts get_location() method to the
more extensive reference documentation about option locations.

Change-Id: Ic9850afd78a7b42f4e807b04e78729a674942e15
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Increase VM SSH timeouts
messages: [{'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:35:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 290, 'date': '2018-06-15 16:02:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1\n\nYeah, I've noticed this happens occasionally, but it's usually because one of the VMs fails to install (gets stuck during install).  Would be nice in the future to restart VMs that fail on the first pass and wait one more timeout period to see if they complete the second time.  That way you don't have to restart the entire job just for one VM failure."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-15 18:55:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-15 20:58:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 15:35:35.000000000', 'message': 'Increase VM SSH timeouts

Occasionally the VM check times out, this relaxes the checks a bit to
decrease failures.

Change-Id: Ic327efb7a86b20bc3f97f3ced2fe3fc54b93d347
'}]
commit_message:
Increase VM SSH timeouts

Occasionally the VM check times out, this relaxes the checks a bit to
decrease failures.

Change-Id: Ic327efb7a86b20bc3f97f3ced2fe3fc54b93d347

test_list_all_implied_roles test. This is because we intend to add

uncommented once the referenced patch merges.

commit_message:
Filter out implied roles

This filters out the irrelevant implied roles, so we only consider the
ones that are actually used in the test. This gives us a more strict and
correct test, which also works when we have the new default rules that
come from the basic-default-roles blueprint.

Change-Id: I4827be8e62b57b1def420e66bed1a95af7bc8007
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572243/

commit_message:
Update feature freeze policy

The feature freeze policy has fallen somewhat out of date due to
changes in the OpenStack release process and in Oslo itself.  This
updates the policy to better reflect the current state of releases.

Change-Id: Ie6637a3eeaa9e04acc86e25b3c1f0b8dcb68a2a5

subject: fix tox python3 overrides
messages:
[{'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-06 19:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-06-07 09:08:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-06-08 05:35:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9414, 'date': '2018-06-08 06:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-06-15 17:24:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

+1 in theory, but in practice do we even really need any tox(python) targets, in a respository whose *only* python file is setup.py itself?'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-06-15 17:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

At least for the pep8 environment, it helps with constraining flake8. We could probably completely kill venv.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-06-15 18:45:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> At least for the pep8 environment, it helps with constraining
 > flake8. We could probably completely kill venv.

Yeah, if you're running flake8 I recommend taking the change. The venv environment used to be integral to many of the packaging and documentation jobs. I don't know if those apply to this repository or not. You could try removing it and see what happens."}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2018-06-15 18:52:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

You can run tox -epep8 -- -v in this repo to see that it is pretty much useless.

I'll take the patch as-is for now... I might eventually make the pep8 target more useful by adding bashate to it, as we've done in sahara.git"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-06 19:28:31.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Id456fc88170c4466a434100934e150f403e7ecd9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Id456fc88170c4466a434100934e150f403e7ecd9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-13 23:19:51.000000000', 'message': 'Render once when all peers are available

The percona-cluster charm was rendering, and therefore, restarting
after each peer joined. This causes race conditions with the leader
handing out client credentials.

This change guarantees the configuration file is rendered only once,
after all peers are available to avoid unnecessary restarts.

Change-Id: I0998407fcb5efbdb0f7734ac39363e8d41088c79
Closes-Bug: #1775682
'}, {'created': '2018-06-14 22:47:39.000000000', 'message': 'Cluster peers notify readiness

The percona-cluster charm was rendering, and therefore, restarting
after each peer joined. This causes race conditions with the leader
handing out client credentials.

This is due to the parallel but conflicting goals of building the
cluster as quickly as possible but also delaying client relations until
the full cluster is completely ready.

The charm relied on the bootstrap_uuid being set among peers. However,
the bootstrap_uuid is set intentionally early in pursuit of the first
goal building the cluster quickly. It did not signify true readiness.

This change adds another peer relation setting, "ready", that each node
sets when it has bootstrapped, its hacluster is complete, and it has a
sufficient number of peers.

The cluster is considered ready when (min-cluster-size) peers have
indicated readiness. This fulfils goal number two delaying client
relations until the full cluster is ready.

Change-Id: I0998407fcb5efbdb0f7734ac39363e8d41088c79
Closes-Bug: #1775682
'}, {'created': '2018-06-15 17:24:36.000000000', 'message': 'Cluster peers notify readiness

The percona-cluster charm was rendering, and therefore, restarting
after each peer joined. This causes race conditions with the leader
handing out client credentials.

This is due to the parallel but conflicting goals of building the
cluster as quickly as possible but also delaying client relations until
the full cluster is completely ready.

The charm relied on the bootstrap_uuid being set among peers. However,
the bootstrap_uuid is set intentionally early in pursuit of the first
goal building the cluster quickly. It did not signify true readiness.

This change adds another peer relation setting, "ready", that each node
sets when it has bootstrapped, its hacluster is complete, and it has a
sufficient number of peers.

The cluster is considered ready when (min-cluster-size) peers have
indicated readiness. This fulfils goal number two delaying client
relations until the full cluster is ready.

Change-Id: I0998407fcb5efbdb0f7734ac39363e8d41088c79
Closes-Bug: #1775682
'}]
commit_message:
Cluster peers notify readiness

The percona-cluster charm was rendering, and therefore, restarting
after each peer joined. This causes race conditions with the leader
handing out client credentials.

This is due to the parallel but conflicting goals of building the
cluster as quickly as possible but also delaying client relations until
the full cluster is completely ready.

The charm relied on the bootstrap_uuid being set among peers. However,
the bootstrap_uuid is set intentionally early in pursuit of the first
goal building the cluster quickly. It did not signify true readiness.

This change adds another peer relation setting, "ready", that each node
sets when it has bootstrapped, its hacluster is complete, and it has a
sufficient number of peers.

The cluster is considered ready when (min-cluster-size) peers have
indicated readiness. This fulfils goal number two delaying client
relations until the full cluster is ready.

Change-Id: I0998407fcb5efbdb0f7734ac39363e8d41088c79
Closes-Bug: #1775682

[{'created': '2018-03-15 16:23:05.000000000', 'message': "Define a 'none' fail-back file for nodes config

This commit adds a new node configuration file named none.yml which
defines an empty topology.
This will give quickstart two benefits:

1 - Not messing with the actual fail-back (1ctlr_1comp.yml) that defines
    an override for node names (with literally foo and bar) that can
    create problems when a user do not pass a node file and wants at the
    same time a setup with more than one controller;

2 - Help with baremetal deployments in which the user don't need to
    define any kind of virtual nodes;

Change-Id: Id02a6d32df39bfa7667d500e4966d10b8b49b8c6

commit_message:
Define a 'baremetal' file for nodes config

This commit adds a new node configuration file named baremetal.yml which
defines an empty topology.
This patch will give quickstart two benefits:

1 - Not messing with the actual fail-back (1ctlr_1comp.yml) that defines
    an override for node names (with literally foo and bar) that can
    create problems when a user do not pass a node file and wants at the
    same time a setup with more than one controller;

2 - Help with baremetal deployments in which the user don't need to
    define any kind of virtual nodes, so it will be enough for a user to
    pass -n baremetal.yml to be sure that nothing will be created on the
    virtual side of things;

Change-Id: Id02a6d32df39bfa7667d500e4966d10b8b49b8c6

commit_message:
Add aggregate metadata unset support to nova_aggregate

Feature was waiting for python-openstackclient to add support
for the "openstack aggregate unset" command. This is now available in 2.4.0.

Closes-bug: #1776772

commit_message:
Unreadable output of upload-to-image.

The output of upload-to-image is not readable due to
volume type is printed in output as a whole.
Printing volume type name only cleans up the output.

Change-Id: Ia588cf7ccc0873a8cf956c551afcccf4b6ddaa39
Closes-Bug: #1557486

commit_message:
MNAIO: Add access to libvirt v4 via UCA Queens

When using an Ubuntu Xenial host, this patch adds the Ubuntu
Cloud Archive Queens repository so that the MNAIO tooling
makes use of libvirt v4. This provides access to a better
snapshot and snapshot-revert implementation, among other
features.

To improve the chances of success during builds, retries
are added to the package install tasks. Also, given that
we're using Ansible > 2.1.x, we forgo the with_items loop
for the package installs and just give the package module
the list so that it installs them all at once.

Change-Id: I0373e29fb996de1538465277760a0181289cbb44

Granted, folks upgrading should be reading all the deprecation notices, but I think it's been done for thoroughness in all of the past patches like this.

I'm usually for over communicating on things like this, but if you think that's overkill, I guess I would be fine just sticking with one (probably the deprecations section if I had to pick one of the two)."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2018-06-15 15:44:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Mark DataCore Drivers unsupported

The DataCore drivers have not run 3rd Party CI
in more than 60 days.  This patch marks them
unsupported and they will be removed in Stein
if the 3rd Party CI Issues are not resolved.

Change-Id: Id0f7ff5c1e8d0973941c9635558a6bd9d2204aea

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-09 11:50:39.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I724fee4ab31762582cb96fc91d99d62b6e637969

commit_message:
bagpipe-bgp: Update object lifecycle manager

Add find object method.

Modify get/free object methods to additionnaly return for a user:
* if first object user when get object called,
* if last object user when free object called.

Signed-off-by: Thomas Morin <thomas.morin@orange.com>
Submitted on behalf of a third-party: Orange

Change-Id: I2ff02a110ceabd5de6d5edeb37fc31f8738e1c14

commit_message:
MNAIO: Use file instead of command for disk image clean-up

Rather than use the command module, we use the file module
which is idempotent. We also remove the conditional for the
clean up so that it's easier to switch between back-ends
and still have the clean-up happen.

Change-Id: I5d77bbd236d1cb7d45bc4dda4206475b5663b1c0

It seems necessary to do this. I don't fully understand why, but I

any case, if I do not do this, the field is unset when I receive it at

commit_message:
DNM: objects: Store RequestSpec.numa_networks

It seems necessary to do this. I don't fully understand why, but I
suspect it's something to do with how we pass this across the wire. In
any case, if I do not do this, the field is unset when I receive it at
the scheduler from the conductor.

Part of blueprint numa-aware-vswitches

Change-Id: Ia047c5a757b10c813d37359c59283f1bcd323f49

commit_message:
Convert Nova APIs to WSGI services

* convert nova-api, metadata to WSGI services
* use nova-api for the Debian compute service to be consistent with the
  install guide[0]

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/queens/install/controller-install-ubuntu.html

Change-Id: I6b06d47a1c407831def591ba68003d7df89523ef

commit_message:
Adds the configuration of bios interfaces

It allows to set the enabled_bios_interfaces and default_bios_interface.
Currently only no-bios interface is possible to add.

Change-Id: I4960b55382b4ef60fefc147a2ae4fca3daa9432b

subject: Do not install tmux
messages: [{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-15 09:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-15 13:11:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nlist probably needs a cleanup but yeah, unnecessary.'}, {'account_id': 13095, 'date': '2018-06-15 13:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-06-15 16:02:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from cleanup_packages_to_install to sles'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 09:39:16.000000000', 'message': 'Do not install tmux

Without this patch, tmux is installed on all the nodes, but
never used.

This is a problem, because some distributions of those three
families (for example SLE) may have decided to not ship tmux
because they ship some other terminal emulator, for example screen.

This patch solves the problem by removing the package that is not
used in any way.

Change-Id: I29f78be4c692fc276e82c3eb71a237614dd7cca0
'}]
commit_message:
Do not install tmux

Without this patch, tmux is installed on all the nodes, but
never used.

This is a problem, because some distributions of those three
families (for example SLE) may have decided to not ship tmux
because they ship some other terminal emulator, for example screen.

This patch solves the problem by removing the package that is not
used in any way.

Change-Id: I29f78be4c692fc276e82c3eb71a237614dd7cca0

commit_message:
Make auth_encryption_key a secret

auth_encryption_key is used to encrypt autentication info in the
database, it must be a secret.

Change-Id: Ib15db2632d087b91ca4923a64fa9923daa6b2c85

'}]
commit_message:
[DNM] Add support for rbd user

Read the rbd_user from the [powervm] section in the conf file.
Use the rbd_user when creating an rbd object. This user id will be
used when trying to connect to the rbd cluster.

Change-Id: I4548eff8afa85e63a8ca40d819298dccffe63e26

commit_message:
Debian: no fwaas l3 extensions

Looks like fwaas extensions are making a bunch of functional tests fail
in Debian, probably because of issues in neutron-rpc-server. We disable
it here, at least temporarily, and for Debian only, so that we have a
working tempest run for Debian. This may be reverted later on once a
better solution is found.

Change-Id: I723bb97310dfb2a737ddcdb79caa2a02ef4e211b

[{'created': '2018-06-12 17:10:35.000000000', 'message': 'Remove server_default comparison logic

Added a new test case that covers comparison of a MySQL server default
defined as text("0") in the model as well as in the database.   The
MySQL default comaprison logic in oslo.db was not accommodating of the
model side here being a text() construct.   As modern Alembic
versions support all the use cases tested here, all the server
default comparison routines can be removed, allowing the new
test to pass as well as all the existing ones.

commit_message:
Remove most server_default comparison logic

Added a new test case that covers comparison of a MySQL server default
defined as text("0") in the model as well as in the database.   The
MySQL default comaprison logic in oslo.db was not accommodating of the
model side here being a text() construct.   As modern Alembic
versions supports most of the use cases tested here,
remove all server defaut comparison logic except for the boolean
comparison workaround.

Alembic minimum is bumped to 0.9.6; the issue repaired between
0.8.10 and 0.9.6 is http://alembic.zzzcomputing.com/en/latest/
changelog.html#change-5459a7552a17d8b658f0f710bedf6da0

Depends-on: I1a8244edae47b04b7b1fed54e577d6534945bcd8
Closes-bug: #1776527
Change-Id: I48a103e28d86128ea84466da4d9d6faab1dd9a9d

commit_message:
Remove PyPI downloads

According to official site,
https://packaging.python.org/guides/analyzing-pypi-package-downloads/
PyPI package download statistics is no longer maintained and thus
should be removed.

Change-Id: I2a2b3970abb9c66b5a1db70248726a0fc6fb37a4

[{'created': '2018-06-07 11:00:44.000000000', 'message': 'Separate migration steps for DHCP / MTU

The DHCP MTU steps need to be separated into

1) Updating the dhcp agent t1 parameter, so the VMs
   will start renewing the MTU details more quickly

2) Updating the MTU parameters on private vxlan networks.

Otherwise when the MTU is updated the VMs will still be renewing
on the old lease time for a very long time (>24h) until they
attempt a new renew and get the new T1 parameter from DHCP
server.

Change-Id: I0570fdc38ea62ba254cf425dab7c3ccc5796aebf

commit_message:
Separate migration steps for DHCP / MTU

The DHCP MTU steps need to be separated into

1) Updating the dhcp agent t1 parameter, so the VMs
   will start renewing the MTU details more quickly

2) Updating the MTU parameters on private vxlan networks.

Otherwise when the MTU is updated the VMs will still be renewing
on the old lease time for a very long time (>24h) until they
attempt a new renew and get the new T1 parameter from DHCP
server.

Change-Id: I0570fdc38ea62ba254cf425dab7c3ccc5796aebf

commit_message:
dev mode: Add support for telegraf

Provide support for kolla dev mode in telegraf. When
'kolla_dev_mode' or 'telegraf_dev_mode' variables are
enabled, source code of telegraf project is cloned
and bindmounted.

Partially implements: blueprint mount-sources

Change-Id: Iacc1c3680c9ca252b1fb160d91c4c2c7f5c58b0a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-08 13:48:52.000000000', 'message': '[OVS] Add mac-table-size to be set on each ovs bridge

By default number of MAC addresses which ovs stores in memory
is quite low - 2048.

Any eviction of a MAC learning table entry triggers revalidation.
Such revalidation is very costly so it cause high CPU usage by
ovs-vswitchd process.

To workaround this problem, higher value of mac-table-size
option can be set for bridge. Then this revalidation will happen
less often and CPU usage will be lower.
This patch adds config option for neutron-openvswitch-agent to allow
users tune this setting in bridges managed by agent.
By default this value is set to 50000 which should be enough for most
systems.

Change-Id: If628f52d75c2b5fec87ad61e0219b3286423468c
Closes-Bug: #1775797
'}, {'created': '2018-06-08 14:30:21.000000000', 'message': '[OVS] Add mac-table-size to be set on each ovs bridge

By default number of MAC addresses which ovs stores in memory

Such revalidation is very costly so it cause high CPU usage by

commit_message:
[OVS] Add mac-table-size to be set on each ovs bridge

By default number of MAC addresses which ovs stores in memory
is quite low - 2048.

Any eviction of a MAC learning table entry triggers revalidation.
Such revalidation is very costly so it cause high CPU usage by
ovs-vswitchd process.

To workaround this problem, higher value of mac-table-size
option can be set for bridge. Then this revalidation will happen
less often and CPU usage will be lower.
This patch adds config option for neutron-openvswitch-agent to allow
users tune this setting in bridges managed by agent.
By default this value is set to 50000 which should be enough for most
systems.

Change-Id: If628f52d75c2b5fec87ad61e0219b3286423468c
Closes-Bug: #1775797

messages:
